# 總裁報告

2016年的全球政經舞台上「黑天鵝」身影頻仍，英國脫歐公投和美國總統大選結果固然令各種民調淪為笑柄，但更出乎意料的卻是金融市場的反應。以美國大選為例，特朗普當選消息令美股三大指數的期貨在開市前急挫，但開市不久美股指數隨即反彈，此後凱歌高奏，屢創新高。連串事件，凸顯了傳統智慧和思維對預測市場能力的局限性，也標誌着未來環球局勢發展的重大不確定性。

過去一年，多項主要金融數據都反映市場情緒異常敏感：美國十年期國庫債券收益率在7月跌至1.36厘歷史低位後，在美國總統大選後的12月中旬飆升至2.6厘。反映美元兌一籃子貨幣走勢的美匯指數在年底升至14年高位；紐約原油期貨價格由年初每桶26美元低位反彈至年底的54美元。本港股市方面，恒生指數全年微升86點，但期內峰谷差逾6,000點。外圍形勢驚濤駭浪，更形金融體系尤其是貨幣和銀行體系穩定的重要和可貴。

2016年1月，國際對沖基金部署狙擊人民幣和港元的傳言甚囂塵上，人心虛怯。金管局迅即向市場發放明確、堅定的訊息，我們絕對有信心、有能力捍衛聯匯制度和香港的金融體系穩定，適時穩住了市場信心。綜觀2016年全年，港元長時間貼近強方兌換保證。由於銀行體系資金非常充裕，即使去年12月和今年3月美國聯儲局加息，對港元利率和匯率並未有明顯的即時影響。

香港銀行體系繼續穩步發展，去年整體貸款錄得6.5%溫和增長，資產質素保持良好，不良貸款比率維持在0.85%的健康水平，遠低於2000年以來約2%的長期平均水平。銀行體系的資本充足率和流動性比率均保持在高於法定要求的高水平。在樓宇按揭業務方面，經過七輪逆周期措施，新造住宅物業按揭平均成數從2009年9月的64%下降至2016年底的51%，平均供款與入息比率也從2010年8月的41%下降至2016年底的34%，為樓市周期一旦逆轉而令銀行體系受到衝擊時，提供了所需的緩衝。金管局會繼續密切留意樓市的發展，因應周期變化而採取合適措施，以保持銀行體系穩定。

進一步強化銀行體系穩定的立法工作去年取得令人鼓舞的進展。優化存款保障制度和針對金融機構「大得不能倒」風險的兩條法例，及時在上屆立法會任期屆滿前順利通過。前者加快存款保障金的發放速度，簡化發放程序，有助加強存戶對銀行體系的信心；後者則為包括銀行在內的金融機構建立處置機制，防範這些機構一旦倒閉而引發的系統性金融風險，並盡量避免動用公帑為它們「包底埋單」。金管局已在今年4月1日設立處置機制辦公室，落實執行法例的要求和跟進工作。

銀行業素有「百業之母」之稱，是實體經濟和普羅市民日常生活倚重的儲蓄、支付渠道和信貸來源。年內，部分中小企業界代表反映融資有困難。金管局即時與銀行界溝通，希望銀行在維持審慎風險管理的情況下，盡可能為中小企的營運和發展繼續提供資金支援。我們又透過轄下香港按揭證券公司，加強向工商界推廣政府的「中小企融資擔保計劃」，並與銀行業界緊密溝通，以釋除疑慮、釐清誤解及理順處理壞帳的索償程序，從而提高銀行參與該計劃的意願。多管齊下，收到了一定成效，根據金管局對銀行進行的調查，中小企整體信貸額度在去年保持平穩，超過九成企業的信貸額度得以維持甚至增加。同時，「中小企融資擔保計劃」的申請數字亦明顯上升。

近年來金管局大力推動普及金融，就是考慮到基本銀行服務已是營商和日常生活不可或缺的環節。去年當我們得知有些海外公司和初創企業在香港開戶遇到困難後，旋即展開跟進工作，與多個國際商會和企業協會聯繫，並跟銀行業界深入溝通，對症下藥。去年9月我向香港所有銀行簽發通告，闡釋應如何理解金管局針對反洗錢和恐怖分子資金籌集活動的「風險為本」監管原則，如何將這項原則應用在開戶申請和對現有客戶的盡職審查措施上，強調銀行不應對所有客戶採用「一刀切」的要求和程序。經我們與銀行和商界協商後，企業開戶情況有所改善，但仍有進步空間，這也是我們今年工作重點之一。

普及金融還涉及銀行分行服務的覆蓋面。金管局一直鼓勵銀行在營商圖利之餘，也要顧及市民的基本銀行服務需要。金融科技一日千里，銀行提供服務的渠道也更趨多元化。除了日益普及的網上銀行服務外，去年多家銀行紛紛推出流動銀行車或視像櫃員機服務，提供較傳統櫃員機更貼身、更全面的銀行服務。在我們的推動下，多家銀行也計劃在偏遠地區設立實體分行，加強對當區居民的服務。

金融中心的發展就如逆水行舟，因此，金管局多年來不斷為香港金融業發展尋求新的契機，開拓新的領域。2016年可說是成果豐碩的一年，當中又以金融科技(Fintech)和基建融資為亮點。

在金融科技方面，香港的零售支付服務在2016年進入新時代。金管局去年發出13個儲值支付工具牌照，通過發牌和恒常監管制度為零售支付服務創造有利的營商環境，配以一系列公眾教育宣傳，讓消費者在享受新科技帶來的便捷之餘，權益也得到合理保障。

此外，去年3月金管局成立了金融科技促進辦公室，以此平台推動與銀行業相關的金融科技發展。幾個月間，我們推出多項新猷，包括「網絡防衛計劃」(Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative)，為強化銀行體系網絡安全建立風險評估、資訊共享和人才培訓三足鼎立的新平台。我們並與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作，開展分布式分類帳技術(distributed ledger technology)專項研究，探討該技術在香港銀行業應用的可行性，並在應科院設立金融科技創新中心(Fintech Innovation Hub)，為銀行業界和金融科技界提供技術支援。金管局的銀行監管部門還設立「金融科技監管沙盒」(Fintech Supervisory Sandbox)，讓銀行在較小和可控範圍內測試新技術的應用，為新產品、新服務的開發提速。自去年9月至今年3月，已有6家銀行共14項新技術項目使用沙盒進行測試，部分項目亦已相繼推出市場，為市民帶來更多金融科技的新產品。

世界各地對基建融資的需求巨大，特別是「一帶一路」倡議提出以來，基建融資更成中外矚目的議題。香港是亞洲的國際金融中心，在基建融資領域極具優勢。去年7月金管局成立了基建融資促進辦公室(Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office，簡稱IFFO)，搭建一個嶄新和獨特的平台，匯聚60多家世界級的多邊機構、機構投資者、銀行、保險公司和其他金融機構、基建項目的建設和營運方、各類專業機構等，就基建投融資課題互通訊息、交流經驗、尋求合作機會。IFFO成立至今已舉辦十多場大型會議、研討會和工作坊，金管局並分別與國際金融公司(International Finance Corporation)、全球基礎設施中心(Global Infrastructure Hub)、國家開發銀行(China Development Bank)和中國進出口銀行(The Export-Import Bank of China)簽署了共同促進基建投融資活動的《諒解備忘錄》。起步時間雖然不長，但為香港未來作為基建投融資中心奠下堅實的基礎。

拆牆鬆綁是提升競爭力的不二法門。年內，金管局積極參與和支援特區政府修訂稅務條例，向在港經營集團內部財資業務的企業提供有利的稅務環境。我們並積極接觸跨國企業，吸引它們來港發展或擴充企業財資活動，藉此進一步強化香港金融市場的功能。

去年的離岸人民幣市場處於調整期。受市場波動和對人民幣匯率預期等因素影響，全球離岸人民幣資金池規模普遍收縮。儘管如此，香港仍穩執離岸人民幣業務的牛耳，保持全球最大的人民幣資金池，經香港結算的人民幣維持在日均約8,600億元人民幣高位。為進一步優化香港離岸人民幣市場的流動性安排，去年10月我們將一級流動性提供行由7家增至9家，支援雙邊流動資金的總額度由原來的140億元人民幣增至180億元，確保在離岸人民幣市場資金出現緊絀的情況下，仍可保持市場有序運作。去年12月股票市場「深港通」開通，令香港的人民幣業務再添動力。金管局亦正與內地有關當局研究「債券通」方案，進一步便利兩地投資者參與債券市場，並優化債券市場基礎設施的聯繫。

儘管去年全球投資環境充斥着各種不穩因素，但有賴於過去一段時間所採取的多項防禦性部署，外匯基金去年錄得681億港元投資收入。自1994年以來外匯基金的複合年度投資回報率達4.8%，高於同期2.1%的本地通脹率。

外匯基金將繼續推動多元化投資，包括進一步擴展資產類別，加大對於信貸資產、抵禦通脹類投資產品和新興市場的投資。而作為多元化投資旗艦的「長期增長組合」，透過私募股權和房地產項目等投資於另類資產。該組合自2009年啟動以來一直保持不俗的成績，成立至今的平均內部回報率年率約12%，而隨着政府「未來基金」部分投放於該組合，我們加快了投資步伐，去年底「長期增長組合」的資產規模約1,818億港元，已批出但未提取作投資的總額約1,338億港元。外匯基金將繼續恪守「保本先行、長期增值」的投資策略，在保持充裕的流動性和備用資金的前提下，尋求長遠穩定的回報。

# Chief Executive’s Statement

The year 2016 saw frequent occurrences of "black swans" on the global political and economic stage. While the results of the UK’s Brexit referendum and the US presidential election rendered various polls laughable, the reactions of financial markets were even more unexpected. Take the US election as an example: news of Trump’s victory caused the futures of the three major US stock indices to plunge before the market opened, but the indices rebounded shortly after opening and continued to hit new highs. These events highlight the limitations of traditional wisdom and thinking in predicting market behaviour and signal significant uncertainties in future global developments.

Over the past year, several key financial indicators reflected unusually sensitive market sentiment: the yield on 10-year US Treasury bonds fell to a historic low of 1.36% in July, then soared to 2.6% in mid-December after the US presidential election. The US dollar index, which reflects the greenback’s performance against a basket of currencies, rose to a 14-year high at the end of the year; New York crude oil futures rebounded from a low of US$26 per barrel at the beginning of the year to US$54 at the end. As for Hong Kong’s stock market, the Hang Seng Index rose slightly by 86 points for the year, but the peak-to-trough difference during the period exceeded 6,000 points. The turbulent external environment underscores the importance and value of financial stability, particularly in the monetary and banking systems.

In January 2016, rumours that international hedge funds were planning to attack the renminbi and the Hong Kong dollar caused widespread anxiety. The HKMA promptly sent a clear and firm message to the market that we had absolute confidence and ability to defend the linked exchange rate system and maintain Hong Kong’s financial stability, which helped to stabilise market confidence in a timely manner. Throughout 2016, the Hong Kong dollar remained close to the strong side of its convertibility undertaking for a long time. As the banking system was flush with funds, even though the US Federal Reserve raised interest rates in December 2016 and March 2017, there was no significant immediate impact on Hong Kong dollar interest rates and the exchange rate.

Hong Kong’s banking system continued to grow steadily last year, with overall loans recording a moderate growth of 6.5%. Asset quality remained sound, with the classified loan ratio staying at a healthy level of 0.85%, far below the long-term average of around 2% since 2000. The banking system’s capital adequacy ratios and liquidity ratios both remained at high levels above statutory minimum requirements. In the mortgage lending business, after seven rounds of countercyclical measures, the average loan-to-value ratio for new residential property mortgages fell from 64% in September 2009 to 51% at the end of 2016, and the average debt-servicing ratio fell from 41% in August 2010 to 34% at the end of 2016, providing a necessary buffer in case the property market cycle reverses and impacts the banking system. The HKMA will continue to closely monitor property market developments and take appropriate measures in response to cyclical changes to maintain banking stability.

Legislative work to further strengthen banking stability made encouraging progress last year. Two pieces of legislation – one to improve the Deposit Protection Scheme and the other to address the "too big to fail" risk of financial institutions – were passed just before the end of the last Legislative Council term. The former speeds up the payout of deposit protection funds and simplifies the payout process, helping to strengthen depositors’ confidence in the banking system; the latter establishes a resolution regime for financial institutions, including banks, to prevent systemic financial risks arising from the failure of these institutions and to avoid using public funds to "bail them out" as much as possible. The HKMA established a Resolution Office on 1 April this year to implement the requirements of the legislation and follow up on its work.

The banking industry has long been known as "the mother of all industries" and is a vital source of savings, payment channels and credit for the real economy and ordinary citizens’ daily lives. During the year, some representatives of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) reported difficulties in obtaining financing. The HKMA immediately communicated with the banking sector, hoping that banks would continue to provide financial support for SMEs’ operations and development as much as possible while maintaining prudent risk management. We also, through our subsidiary the Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation, stepped up promotion of the government’s SME Financing Guarantee Scheme to the business sector and maintained close communication with the banking sector to address concerns, clarify misunderstandings and streamline the claims process for handling bad debts, thereby increasing banks’ willingness to participate in the scheme. These efforts have yielded some results: according to a survey conducted by the HKMA on banks, overall credit facility limits for SMEs remained stable last year, with more than 90% of enterprises maintaining or even increasing their credit facility limits. At the same time, applications for the SME Financing Guarantee Scheme also increased significantly.

In recent years, the HKMA has vigorously promoted financial inclusion, recognising that basic banking services are essential for business and daily life. Last year, when we learned that some overseas companies and start-up companies were having difficulty opening accounts in Hong Kong, we immediately followed up, contacting several international chambers of commerce and SME associations and communicating closely with the banking sector to address the problem. In September last year, I issued a circular to all banks in Hong Kong explaining how to understand the HKMA’s "risk-based" regulatory principles for anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing activities, how to apply these principles to account opening applications and due diligence measures for existing customers, and emphasising that banks should not adopt a "one-size-fits-all" approach and procedures for all customers. After our consultations with banks and the business sector, the situation regarding corporate account opening has improved, but there is still room for progress, which is one of our work priorities this year.

Financial inclusion also involves the coverage of bank branch services. The HKMA has always encouraged banks to, while pursuing profits, also take into account the basic banking service needs of citizens. Financial technology is advancing rapidly, and banks’ service channels are becoming more diversified. In addition to the increasingly popular online banking services, many banks launched mobile bank branches or video teller machines last year, providing more personalised and comprehensive banking services than traditional ATMs. Under our encouragement, several banks also plan to set up physical branches in remote areas to enhance services to local residents.

The development of a financial centre is akin to swimming against the tide: if you don’t move forward, you fall back. That’s why the HKMA has been continuously seeking new opportunities and exploring new areas for the development of Hong Kong’s financial industry over the years. 2016 was a fruitful year, with financial technology (fintech) and infrastructure financing being the highlights.

In terms of financial technology, Hong Kong’s retail payment services entered a new era in 2016. Last year, the HKMA issued 13 stored value facility licences, creating a favourable business environment for retail payment services through a licensing and supervisory regime, coupled with a series of public education campaigns, so that consumers can enjoy the convenience brought by new technology while having their rights and interests reasonably protected.

In addition, the HKMA established a Fintech Facilitation Office in March last year to promote fintech development related to the banking industry through this platform. Within a few months, we launched several new initiatives, including the Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative, which establishes a new platform based on risk assessment, information sharing and talent training to strengthen the cybersecurity of the banking system. We also collaborated with the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) to conduct a special study on distributed ledger technology to explore its feasibility for application in Hong Kong’s banking industry, and established a Fintech Innovation Hub at ASTRI to provide technical support for the banking and fintech sectors. The HKMA’s Banking Supervision Department also established a Fintech Supervisory Sandbox to allow banks to test new technologies in a smaller and more controlled environment, accelerating the development of new products and services. From September last year to March this year, six banks conducted tests on 14 new technology projects using the sandbox, and some of the projects have already been launched on the market, bringing more fintech products to citizens.

There is huge demand for infrastructure financing around the world, and it has become a topic of interest both at home and abroad, especially since the launch of the Belt and Road Initiative. Hong Kong, as Asia’s international financial centre, has a strong advantage in infrastructure financing. In July last year, the HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO), a new and unique platform that brings together more than 60 world-class multilateral organisations, institutional investors, banks, insurance companies and other financial institutions, infrastructure project developers and operators, and various professional firms to exchange information, share experiences and explore cooperation opportunities on infrastructure investment and financing issues. Since its establishment, IFFO has organised more than a dozen large-scale conferences, seminars and workshops, and the HKMA has signed memoranda of understanding with the International Finance Corporation, the Global Infrastructure Hub, the China Development Bank and the Export-Import Bank of China to jointly promote infrastructure investment and financing activities. Although it has not been long since its establishment, IFFO has laid a solid foundation for Hong Kong’s future as an infrastructure investment and financing centre.

Removing barriers is key to enhancing competitiveness. During the year, the HKMA actively participated in and supported the HKSAR government’s revision of tax laws to provide a favourable tax environment for companies operating corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong. We also actively approached multinational corporations to attract them to develop or expand their corporate treasury activities in Hong Kong, thereby further strengthening the functions of Hong Kong’s financial market.

The offshore renminbi market was in an adjustment period last year. Affected by market volatility and expectations of the renminbi exchange rate, the size of the global offshore renminbi liquidity pool generally shrank. Nevertheless, Hong Kong remained the leader in offshore renminbi business, maintaining the world’s largest renminbi liquidity pool, with renminbi settlement through Hong Kong averaging around RMB860 billion per day. To further optimise Hong Kong’s offshore renminbi market liquidity arrangements, in October last year we increased the number of primary liquidity providers from seven to nine, and raised the total amount of bilateral liquidity support from RMB14 billion to RMB18 billion, ensuring that the market can still operate in an orderly manner even if offshore renminbi funds become tight. The launch of the Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect in December last year gave a further boost to Hong Kong’s renminbi business. The HKMA is also working with relevant authorities on the mainland to study a "Bond Connect" scheme to further facilitate participation in the bond market by investors from both sides and optimise the connectivity of bond market infrastructure.

Despite various uncertainties in the global investment environment last year, thanks to the defensive measures taken over the past period, the Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$68.1 billion. Since 1994, the Exchange Fund’s compounded annual investment return has been 4.8%, higher than the local inflation rate of 2.1% over the same period.

The Exchange Fund will continue to promote diversified investment, including further expanding asset classes and increasing investment in credit assets, inflation-linked investment products and emerging markets. As the flagship of diversified investment, the Long-Term Growth Portfolio invests in alternative assets through private equity and real estate projects. The portfolio has performed well since its launch in 2009, with an annualised internal rate of return of around 12%, and with part of the government’s Future Fund being allocated to the portfolio, we have accelerated our investment pace: at the end of last year, the Long-Term Growth Portfolio’s asset size was around HK$181.8 billion, with a total of around HK$133.8 billion approved but not yet drawn down for investment. The Exchange Fund will continue to adhere to the investment strategy of "capital preservation first, long-term growth next", seeking long-term stable returns while maintaining sufficient liquidity and reserve funds.

# 2016年摘要

# 經濟及金融環境

隨着環球經濟及貿易活動疲弱，香港經濟增長回軟。年內本港股市及住宅物業市場波動，置業負擔能力依然偏緊。

儘管環球市場風險及衝擊增加，香港銀行體系仍維持穩健。銀行資本及流動性狀況維持良好；資產質素輕微轉差，但仍處於健康水平。

# 貨幣穩定

儘管面對波動的外圍環境，港元匯率仍然保持穩定，反映聯繫匯率制度承受外來衝擊的能力。

貨幣市場繼續運作暢順，銀行同業流動資金充裕。於12月，繼美國聯邦儲備局決定上調聯邦基金利率目標範圍，香港基本利率上調25基點至1.00厘。

# 銀行體系穩定

金管局加強監管銀行的風險管治架構，以及信用、流動性與科技風險管理。金管局亦採取具體行動，促進普及金融和應對企業在香港開立及維持銀行帳戶遇到的困難。

監管政策方面，就本港實施國際監管及會計標準的準備工作取得重大進展，當中包括《金融機構（處置機制）條例》下的處置框架。

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

香港維持其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐和資產管理中心的地位。稅制獲進一步完善，營造更有利環境，吸引跨國公司在香港設立企業財資中心。

為發展香港成為基建融資中心與金融科技樞紐，金管局成立基建融資促進辦公室及金融科技促進辦公室。金管局順利開始實施儲值支付工具及零售支付系統的監管制度，並批出13個儲值支付工具牌照。

# 儲備管理

儘管投資環境困難，充斥黑天鵝事件，但有賴過去幾年所採取的一連串防禦措施，增強外匯基金的抗震能力，外匯基金錄得2%的整體投資回報。

金管局加快多元化投資的步伐，特別是長期增長組合的投資。

# 機構職能

金管局透過傳媒、公眾教育活動及其他各種渠道與社會和市場保持有效溝通，增進公眾對金管局政策及運作的了解。

金管局繼續加強機構管治，包括推動員工提升專業能力、嚴格控制財政及加強資訊科技保安，以應付推行新措施及日益繁重的工作所帶來的挑戰。

# Summary for 2016

# Economic and Financial Environment

Hong Kong’s economic growth slowed as global economic and trade activity weakened. During the year, the territory’s stock and residential property markets experienced volatility, while housing affordability remained constrained.

Despite heightened risks and shocks in global markets, Hong Kong’s banking system remained robust. Banks’ capital and liquidity positions stayed sound, and although asset quality deteriorated slightly, it remained at a healthy level.

# Monetary Stability

The Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remained stable despite a volatile external environment, demonstrating the resilience of the Linked Exchange Rate System to external shocks.

The money market continued to function smoothly, with ample interbank liquidity. In December, following the US Federal Reserve’s decision to raise the target range for the Federal Funds Rate, Hong Kong’s base rate was increased by 25 basis points to 1.00%.

# Banking System Stability

The HKMA strengthened its oversight of banks’ risk governance frameworks, as well as their credit, liquidity, and technology risk management. It also took concrete steps to promote financial inclusion and address the challenges businesses face in opening and maintaining bank accounts in Hong Kong.

Significant progress was made in regulatory policy, particularly in preparing for the implementation of international supervisory and accounting standards in Hong Kong, including the resolution framework under the Financial Institutions (Resolution) Ordinance.

# Hong Kong’s Status as an International Financial Centre

Hong Kong retained its position as a global hub for offshore renminbi business and as an asset management centre. Further improvements to the tax regime created a more favourable environment for attracting multinational corporations to establish corporate treasury centres in the city.

To develop Hong Kong into an infrastructure financing centre and a fintech hub, the HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office and the Fintech Facilitation Office. The HKMA successfully began implementing the regulatory regime for stored value facilities and retail payment systems, issuing 13 stored value facility licences in the process.

# Reserves Management

Despite a challenging investment environment marked by black swan events, the Exchange Fund achieved an overall investment return of 2%, thanks to a series of defensive measures implemented over the past few years that enhanced its resilience to shocks.

The HKMA accelerated its diversification of investments, particularly in the long-term growth portfolio.

# Corporate Functions

The HKMA maintained effective communication with society and markets through media, public education activities, and other channels, enhancing public understanding of its policies and operations.

The HKMA continued to strengthen its corporate governance, promoting professional development among employees, maintaining strict financial discipline, and enhancing information technology security to address the challenges posed by new initiatives and increasing workloads.

金管局、英倫銀行與國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）在香港合辦「金融危機後貨幣、金融和審慎監管政策的互動」高層次研討會。

IFFO主辦題為「私營資金參與新興市場基建項目的投融資」的首個行政人員工作坊，並宣布再有13家機構加入成為IFFO合作夥伴，令其總數增至超過50個。

金管局擴大人民幣一級流動性提供行計劃，將提供行數目由7家增至9家，並把計劃的總額度增至180億元人民幣。金管局人民幣流動資金安排使用情況的透明度亦增加。

# 11月

# 11月4日

金管局宣布根據《支付條例》批出第二批儲值支付工具牌照，令儲值支付工具持牌人總數增至13個。

# 11月8日

IFFO主辦高層研討會，由亞洲基礎設施投資銀行行長金立群先生析述該行的營運及基建項目。

# 11月11日

金管局舉辦「金融科技日」，並發表分布式分類帳技術的研究白皮書。

金管局與香港應用科技研究院（應科院）合作成立「金融科技創新中心」，以助構思創新意念及試驗嶄新的金融科技技術。

財經事務及庫務局與金管局、證監會及保險業監督聯合發表《金融機構（處置機制）條例》下有關受保障安排建議規例的諮詢文件。

# Key Events of 2016

# January

# 14 January

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) announced that the countercyclical capital buffer ratio applicable to Hong Kong would be raised to 1.25% from 1 January 2017.

# February

# 5 February

The HKMA and the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) published a consultation summary on proposals to introduce mandatory clearing and expand mandatory reporting for the over-the-counter derivatives regulatory regime.

# March

# 21 March

The HKMA established the Fintech Facilitation Office to promote Hong Kong as a fintech hub in Asia.

# May

# 16 May

The HKMA announced that the coin collection programme would be extended for another two years, until September 2018.

# 18 May

At the 2016 Cyber Security Summit, the HKMA announced the launch of the Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative to further enhance the cyber resilience of Hong Kong’s banking sector against cyber attacks.

# June

# 1–2 June

The HKMA and the China Banking Regulatory Commission jointly organised an advanced training course for independent non-executive directors of Hong Kong banks.

# 3 June

The Inland Revenue (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 2016 was gazetted, allowing enterprises to deduct interest expenses on intra-group financing business under specified conditions and providing tax incentives for corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong.

# 10 June

The Securities and Futures (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 was gazetted, introducing a new structure for open-ended fund companies to diversify Hong Kong’s fund domiciliation platform.

# 20 June

The sixth tranche of inflation-linked retail bonds (iBonds) was issued under the Government Bond Programme.

# 30 June

The Financial Institutions (Resolution) Ordinance was gazetted, providing a legal basis for establishing a cross-sector resolution regime for financial institutions in Hong Kong.

# July

# 4 July

The HKMA signed memorandums of understanding with the International Finance Corporation and the Global Infrastructure Hub to promote investment and financing for Asian infrastructure projects through the IFFO platform.

The HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) to promote Hong Kong’s development as an infrastructure financing hub.

# 5 July

The HKMA and the Boao Forum for Asia co-hosted a financial cooperation conference in Hong Kong on the theme of “Finance Facilitating the Real Economy”.

# 20 July

Joint e-cheque clearing between Guangdong (including Shenzhen) and Hong Kong was launched.

# August

# 12 August

The first tranche of Silver Bonds was issued under the Government Bond Programme.

# 25 August

The HKMA announced that, under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (PSSVFO), the first batch of stored value facility (SVF) licences had been granted to five SVF issuers.

# September

# 6 September

The HKMA and the Treasury Markets Association co-hosted the 2016 Treasury Markets Summit in Hong Kong.

The HKMA launched the Fintech Supervisory Sandbox to allow banks to pilot fintech and other technology projects before full implementation.

# 28 September

The HKMA chaired a seminar in Frankfurt, Germany, to promote Hong Kong’s role in capitalising on China’s rising opportunities.

# October

# 24–25 October

The HKMA, the Bank of England, and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) co-hosted a high-level seminar in Hong Kong on “Monetary, Financial and Prudential Policy Interactions in the Post-Crisis World”.

# 26–28 October

IFFO hosted its first executive workshop on “Private Participation in Infrastructure Project Finance in Emerging Markets” and announced that 13 more institutions had joined as IFFO partners, bringing the total to over 50.

# 27 October

The HKMA expanded the renminbi primary liquidity provider (PLP) scheme, increasing the number of providers from seven to nine and raising the total quota to RMB 180 billion. Transparency in the use of the HKMA’s renminbi liquidity facility was also enhanced.

# November

# 4 November

The HKMA announced that, under the PSSVFO, a second batch of SVF licences had been granted, bringing the total number of SVF licensees to 13.

# 8 November

IFFO hosted a senior-level seminar at which President Jin Liqun of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank discussed the bank’s operations and infrastructure projects.

# 11 November

The HKMA hosted Fintech Day and published a white paper on distributed ledger technology.

The HKMA and the Hong Kong Applied Science and Technology Research Institute (ASTRI) jointly established the Fintech Innovation Hub to facilitate the development of innovative ideas and the testing of new fintech technologies.

# 22 November

The Financial Services and the Treasury Bureau, together with the HKMA, the SFC, and the Insurance Authority, jointly published a consultation paper on proposed rules for protected arrangements under the Financial Institutions (Resolution) Ordinance.

The HKMA signed a memorandum of understanding with the Hong Kong Chinese Enterprises Association to help more mainland enterprises establish corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong.

# 經濟及金融環境

隨着環球經濟及貿易活動疲弱，香港經濟增長在2016年回軟。面對外圍環境不明朗因素加劇，預期2017年經濟增長仍然溫和。

# 經濟回顧

# 概覽

香港經濟增長在2016年放緩，實質本地生產總值增長由2015年的2.4%降至1.9%（表1）。淨出口是主要拖累，當中訪港旅遊業疲弱令服務輸出受壓（圖1）。本地需求動力亦放緩，但繼續為整體經濟增長提供主要支持。勞工市場大致保持穩定，失業率維持於3.3至3.4%的低位。由於本地成本及外部價格壓力減退，消費物價通脹進一步放緩。面對波動的外圍環境及多變的市場氣氛，資產市場增添起伏。鑑於住宅物業市場再度暢旺，政府於11月實施新印花稅措施。

儘管外圍環境波動及美元利率上升，本港外匯及貨幣市場繼續運作暢順。港元現貨匯率於1月份略為轉弱後一直在7.75附近水平徘徊。年內兌換保證並無被觸發，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券合計幾乎維持不變，約為1.2萬億港元。繼美國於12月中加息後，金管局基本利率由0.75厘上調至1厘。香港銀行同業拆息及較長期債券收益率維持在相對較低水平，但在接近年底時稍升，部分反映美元相應拆息及收益率的走勢。整體銀行貸款增長在2016年加快至6.5%。雖然整體貸款質素略為轉差，但特定分類貸款比率仍然維持在極低水平。

圖 1 組成部分對實質本地生產總值增長的貢獻
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 本地需求

本地需求的增長力度在2016年略為減弱。儘管穩定的就業及收入狀況繼續為私人消費帶來支持，但其增速仍降至1.6%，部分反映經濟不明朗因素加劇。政府消費增長亦略為減慢至3.3%。本地固定資本形成總額繼續按季大幅上落（圖2），累計全年收縮0.5%。私營部門機器及設備購置成為主要拖累，在營商前景欠佳下連續第3年收縮，而樓宇及建造活動則因住屋動工項目增加而轉殷。

圖 2 本地需求
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 外部需求

香港出口在接近2016年底時有回穩跡象，但綜合全年表現仍然乏力（圖3）。貨品出口較2015年的低基數上升1.7%。香港對先進經濟體的出口仍然呆滯；但在區內貿易流動轉趨穩定下，香港對中國內地、印度、韓國、新加坡及台灣的出口則較2015年好轉。

部分反映零售銷售在近年急速增長後轉趨正常化，香港服務輸出在2016年顯著收縮3.1%。貨品進口在2015年收縮後於2016年收復部分失地，服務輸入則部分受惠於本地居民外遊意欲而持續增長。2016年整體貿易順差收窄，拖累本地經濟增長。

圖 3 貨品出口及服務輸出
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 通脹

通脹壓力在2016年仍然受控。剔除政府一次性紓緩措施的影響後，基本通脹率由2015年的2.5%下降至2016年的2.3%（圖4）。在早前新訂私人住宅租金下調所帶來的傳遞效應下，綜合消費物價指數中的租金組成項目通脹回落。受惠於全球商品價格偏軟及港元強勢，進口價格通脹受到遏抑。另一方面，在勞工成本穩定增長及租金成本壓力（尤其零售範疇）有所紓緩下，本地成本壓力保持溫和。

# 勞工市場

勞工市場在2016年大致保持穩定，勞工供求升幅相若。按行業分析，旅遊相關行業的勞工市場狀況轉差，其他行業則大致平穩。整體而言，經季節因素調整失業率由2015年的3.3%稍升至3.4%（圖5）。在勞工市場穩定下，名義工資在首3季上升3.8%，而2015年的升幅為4.6%。首3季實質工資亦上升0.9%，而2015年的升幅為1.5%。

圖 5 勞工市場狀況
資料來源：政府統計處。

# 股市

香港股市在2016年大幅上落。受到人民幣貶值壓力及內地股市波動所影響，恒生指數於2月份跌至3年來的低位（圖6）。本港股市在3月份跟隨美國及其他主要股市顯著造好而回升。儘管英國脫歐公投觸發市場波動，但在外界預期美國聯邦儲備局會放緩加息步伐及其他主要央行推行貨幣寬鬆政策下，市場氣氛迅速改善。恒生指數於9月份升至24,100點的一年高位。然而，受到美國總統選舉結果及預計美國會加快加息步伐所影響，本港股市在第4季再度受壓。整體而言，恒生指數於2016年微升0.4%，在2015年則下跌7.2%。平均每日成交額由上年的1,056億港元降至669億港元，而本港股市集資總額亦由上年的11,156億港元減少至4,901億港元。

圖 6 資產價格
資料來源：差餉物業估價署及香港交易及結算所有限公司。

# 物業市場

住宅物業市場在2016年略為波動。物業成交量於第1季錄得歷史新低後，在其後數月有所回升，但在11月推出新印花稅措施後再度下挫。整體而言，成交量在2016年稍跌至54,701宗。另一方面，樓價自第2季起上升並超越2015年9月的高位，2016年的累計升幅為7.8%（圖6）。置業負擔能力依然偏緊，樓價與收入比率為15.9，超越1997年的歷史高位；而收入槓桿比率為72.0%，遠高於長期平均水平。2 由於銀行推出具競爭力的按揭計劃，按揭利率稍為回落，於接近年底時則跟隨香港銀行同業拆息上升而略為回升。工商物業市場方面，全年交投大致保持穩定。由於非住宅物業價格較2015年高位回落，相應租金收益率較上年微升，但仍處於低位。

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

預期2017年實質本地生產總值增長將保持溫和。政府預測經濟增長幅度介乎2至3%之間，私營機構分析員預測增幅平均為2.0%。外圍方面，隨着環球宏觀經濟及金融環境變得不明朗，全球經濟及貿易增長或會保持溫和；再加上港元實質有效匯率因美元強勢而上升，將會抑制香港的出口表現。本地方面，雖然穩定的就業及收入狀況會支持消費，但受利率上升所拖累，預期私人消費會溫和增長。受惠於住屋供應增加及多個基建項目展開，樓宇及建造活動應會穩步增長，但營商氣氛疲弱及利率趨升將影響商界資本投資。

# 通脹及勞工市場

預計2017年通脹壓力仍然溫和。一方面環球商品價格上漲及中國內地通脹趨升或會令進口價格上升，另一方面港元轉強卻可能會令上述壓力受到遏抑。在溫和的經濟動力下，本地成本壓力仍可受控，但由於新訂住宅租金於2017年初上升，綜合消費物價指數中的租金組成項目通脹可能會稍升。市場共識預測2017年整體通脹率為1.9%，政府預期基本通脹率為2.0%。雖然不明朗因素加劇或會影響招聘意欲，私營機構分析員預計2017年失業率會維持於3.4%。

# 不明朗因素及風險

2017年經濟前景會受制於眾多不明朗因素，當中來自外圍環境的影響尤甚。美國新一屆政府政策的不確定性，將令環球經濟前景變得不明朗，當中可能出現的保護主義政策亦會對全球貿易帶來阻力。英國脫歐進程及歐洲幾個主要國家舉行大選，亦可能導致資產市場波動，並影響港元資金流向。此外，美國利率正常化將會令本地貨幣狀況收緊，並對實質經濟及資產價格構成下調壓力；當中樓市繼續偏緊，市場前景仍然很不明朗。短期而言，按揭息率仍然偏低、就業及收入狀況穩定，以及地產發展商加推優惠（例如折扣及現金回贈）令累積的購買力獲得釋放，均可為住宅需求帶來支持。另一方面，新印花稅措施、美國可能加快加息步伐及房屋供應穩步增長，則可能繼續為樓市帶來阻力。

# 銀行體系表現

儘管本港經濟面對阻力，加上國際政治事件出乎意料的結果令市場波動加劇，香港銀行體系在2016年仍然穩健。認可機構的資本及流動性狀況維持良好，資產質素輕微轉差，但仍處於健康水平。

# 利率走勢

隨着美國利率上升，香港銀行同業拆息在11月及12月顯著上升。反映零售銀行港元資金成本的綜合利率則輕微上升（圖7）。

# 盈利走勢

零售銀行在2016年的盈利略為改善，其香港業務的整體除稅前經營溢利增長8.7%。增長主要是由外匯及衍生工具業務收入（+39.7%）、附屬公司派發的股息收入（+123.5%）及淨利息收入（+2.8%）所帶動，不過部份增長被費用及佣金收入減少(-11.3%)所抵銷。零售銀行除稅後溢利錄得44.4%的升幅，增長主要來自非經常項目。零售銀行除稅後平均資產回報率亦相應由2015 年的 1.04% 上升至 1.44%（圖 8）。

圖8 零售銀行的表現

2016年零售銀行淨息差為1.32%，與2015年的水平相同（圖9）。雖然零售銀行繼續將剩餘資金配置於息率較低而流動性較高的金融投資，但利息收益的減少被利息成本下降所抵銷。

零售銀行非利息收入佔總經營收入的比例為44.3%，大致維持穩定。雖然費用與佣金收入下跌11.3%，但股息收入及外匯與衍生工具業務收入分別上升123.5%及39.7%。

# Economic and Financial Environment

Hong Kong’s economic growth weakened in 2016 as global economic and trade activity remained sluggish. Faced with heightened uncertainty in the external environment, economic growth is expected to remain moderate in 2017.

# Economic Review

# Overview

Hong Kong’s economic growth slowed in 2016, with real GDP growth falling from 2.4% in 2015 to 1.9% (Table 1). Net exports were the main drag, with weak inbound tourism weighing on service exports (Chart 1). Domestic demand also slowed but continued to provide the main support for overall economic growth. The labour market remained largely stable, with the unemployment rate staying at a low level of 3.3% to 3.4%. Consumer price inflation eased further as local cost and external price pressures subsided. Amid a volatile external environment and fluctuating market sentiment, asset markets became more volatile. In view of the renewed buoyancy in the residential property market, the government implemented new stamp duty measures in November.

Despite the volatile external environment and rising US interest rates, Hong Kong’s foreign exchange and monetary markets continued to operate smoothly. The Hong Kong dollar spot exchange rate weakened slightly in January but then hovered around 7.75. The convertibility undertaking was not triggered during the year, and the aggregate balance together with outstanding Exchange Fund paper remained almost unchanged at around HK$1.2 trillion. Following the US interest rate hike in mid-December, the HKMA Base Rate was raised from 0.75% to 1%. Hong Kong interbank offered rates (HIBORs) and longer-term bond yields remained at relatively low levels but edged up towards the end of the year, partly reflecting the movements of their US counterparts. Overall bank loan growth accelerated to 6.5% in 2016. Although overall loan quality deteriorated slightly, the classified loan ratio remained at a very low level.

Source: Census and Statistics Department.

Note: The quarterly change in gross fixed capital formation adjusted for seasonal factors is not available.
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Domestic Demand

The growth of domestic demand weakened slightly in 2016. Despite stable employment and income conditions continuing to support private consumption, its growth slowed to 1.6%, partly reflecting heightened economic uncertainty. Growth in government consumption also slowed slightly to 3.3%. Gross fixed capital formation continued to fluctuate significantly on a quarterly basis (Chart 2), contracting by 0.5% for the whole year. Machinery and equipment purchases by the private sector were the main drag, contracting for the third consecutive year amid a weak business outlook, while building and construction activities turned more buoyant as a result of increased housing project commencements.

Chart 2 Domestic demand
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# External Demand

Hong Kong’s exports showed signs of stabilisation towards the end of 2016, but overall performance for the year remained weak (Chart 3). Merchandise exports rose by 1.7% from a low base in 2015. Hong Kong’s exports to advanced economies remained sluggish; but exports to the mainland, India, Korea, Singapore and Taiwan improved from 2015 as regional trade flows stabilised.

Partly reflecting the normalisation of retail sales after rapid growth in recent years, Hong Kong’s service exports contracted significantly by 3.1% in 2016. Merchandise imports recovered some lost ground in 2016 after contracting in 2015, while service imports continued to grow, partly supported by local residents’ outbound travel demand. The overall trade surplus narrowed in 2016, weighing on domestic economic growth.

Chart 3 Merchandise exports and service exports
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Inflation

Inflationary pressures remained under control in 2016. Excluding the effects of the government’s one-off relief measures, underlying inflation fell from 2.5% in 2015 to 2.3% in 2016 (Chart 4). Amid the pass-through effects of earlier reductions in newly let private residential rentals, inflation of the rental component in the Composite Consumer Price Index eased. Benefiting from weak global commodity prices and a strong Hong Kong dollar, inflation of import prices was contained. On the other hand, local cost pressures remained moderate as labour costs grew steadily and rental cost pressures (especially in the retail sector) eased.

Chart 4 Underlying consumer price inflation
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Labour Market

The labour market remained largely stable in 2016, with similar growth in both labour demand and supply. By industry, labour market conditions worsened in the tourism-related sector, but remained generally stable in other sectors. Overall, the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate edged up slightly from 3.3% in 2015 to 3.4% (Chart 5). Amid a stable labour market, nominal wages rose by 3.8% in the first three quarters, compared with a 4.6% increase in 2015. Real wages also rose by 0.9% in the first three quarters, compared with a 1.5% increase in 2015.

Chart 5 Labour market conditions
Source: Census and Statistics Department.

# Stock Market

Hong Kong’s stock market fluctuated significantly in 2016. Affected by depreciation pressure on the renminbi and volatility in mainland stock markets, the Hang Seng Index fell to a three-year low in February (Chart 6). Hong Kong’s stock market rebounded in March, following significant gains in US and other major stock markets. Despite market volatility triggered by the Brexit referendum, market sentiment improved rapidly amid expectations that the US Federal Reserve would slow the pace of interest rate hikes and other major central banks would implement monetary easing policies. The Hang Seng Index rose to a one-year high of 24,100 in September. However, Hong Kong’s stock market came under pressure again in the fourth quarter, affected by the results of the US presidential election and expectations that the US would accelerate the pace of interest rate hikes. Overall, the Hang Seng Index rose slightly by 0.4% in 2016, after falling by 7.2% in 2015. Average daily turnover fell from HK$105.6 billion in the previous year to HK$66.9 billion, while total funds raised in Hong Kong’s stock market also fell from HK$1,115.6 billion in the previous year to HK$490.1 billion.

Chart 6 Asset prices
Source: Rating and Valuation Department and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited.

# Property Market

The residential property market fluctuated slightly in 2016. Property transaction volume hit a historical low in the first quarter, then rebounded in the following months, but fell again after the introduction of new stamp duty measures in November. Overall, transaction volume fell slightly to 54,701 in 2016. On the other hand, property prices rose from the second quarter and surpassed the high recorded in September 2015, with a cumulative increase of 7.8% in 2016 (Chart 6). Housing affordability remained tight, with the price-to-income ratio at 15.9, surpassing the historical high recorded in 1997; and the income-to-debt ratio at 72.0%, far above the long-term average. 2 Mortgage rates fell slightly as banks launched competitive mortgage programmes, but edged up towards the end of the year as they followed the rise in HIBORs. In the commercial property market, transaction volume remained largely stable throughout the year. As non-residential property prices fell from their 2015 highs, the corresponding rental yields rose slightly from the previous year, but remained at a low level.

# Economic Prospects

# Economic Environment

Real GDP growth is expected to remain moderate in 2017. The government forecasts economic growth of between 2% and 3%, while private sector analysts predict an average growth rate of 2.0%. Externally, as the global macroeconomic and financial environment becomes more uncertain, global economic and trade growth is likely to remain moderate; and the appreciation of the Hong Kong dollar’s real effective exchange rate due to a strong US dollar will weigh on Hong Kong’s export performance. Domestically, although stable employment and income conditions will support consumption, private consumption is expected to grow moderately, dragged down by rising interest rates. Benefiting from increased housing supply and the commencement of various infrastructure projects, building and construction activities should grow steadily, but weak business sentiment and rising interest rates will affect business capital investment.

# Inflation and Labour Market

Inflationary pressures are expected to remain moderate in 2017. On the one hand, rising global commodity prices and inflation in the mainland may push up import prices, but on the other hand, a stronger Hong Kong dollar may contain such pressures. Amid moderate economic momentum, local cost pressures should remain under control, but inflation of the rental component in the Composite Consumer Price Index may edge up slightly as newly let residential rentals rose in early 2017. Market consensus predicts overall inflation of 1.9% in 2017, while the government expects underlying inflation of 2.0%. Although heightened uncertainty may affect hiring intentions, private sector analysts expect the unemployment rate to remain at 3.4% in 2017.

# Uncertainties and Risks

The economic outlook for 2017 will be constrained by numerous uncertainties, particularly those arising from the external environment. The uncertainty surrounding the policies of the new US administration will make the global economic outlook unclear, and potential protectionist policies may also hinder global trade. The Brexit process and elections in several major European countries may also cause volatility in asset markets and affect capital flows in the Hong Kong dollar. In addition, US interest rate normalisation will tighten local monetary conditions and exert downward pressure on the real economy and asset prices; the property market remains tight, and its outlook is still highly uncertain. In the short term, low mortgage rates, stable employment and income conditions, and incentives offered by property developers (such as discounts and cash rebates) that release accumulated purchasing power can all support residential demand. On the other hand, new stamp duty measures, the possibility of faster US interest rate hikes, and steady growth in housing supply may continue to weigh on the property market.

# Performance of the Banking System

Despite headwinds facing Hong Kong’s economy and heightened market volatility caused by unexpected outcomes of international political events, Hong Kong’s banking system remained robust in 2016. Authorised institutions’ capital and liquidity positions remained sound, and asset quality deteriorated slightly but remained healthy.

# Interest Rate Trends

As US interest rates rose, HIBORs rose significantly in November and December. The composite interest rate, which reflects retail banks’ Hong Kong dollar funding costs, rose slightly (Chart 7).

Chart 7 Hong Kong interbank offered rates, composite interest rate and best lending rate

Notes:
1. HIBORs (monthly averages) are published by the Hong Kong Association of Banks.
2. The best lending rate (monthly average) is based on the rate reported by The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited.

# Profitability Trends

Retail banks’ profitability improved slightly in 2016, with overall pre-tax operating profit from their Hong Kong operations rising by 8.7%. The growth was mainly driven by foreign exchange and derivative portfolio income (+39.7%), dividend income from subsidiaries (+123.5%) and net interest income (+2.8%), although part of the growth was offset by a decline in fee and commission income (-11.3%). Retail banks’ post-tax profit rose by 44.4%, with growth mainly coming from non-recurring items. Retail banks’ post-tax return on average assets also rose accordingly from 1.04% in 2015 to 1.44% (Chart 8).

Chart 8 Performance of retail banks

Retail banks’ net interest margin was 1.32% in 2016, the same as in 2015 (Chart 9). Although retail banks continued to allocate surplus funds to financial investments with lower interest rates but higher liquidity, the decline in interest income was offset by a decline in interest costs.

Chart 9 Retail banks’ net interest margin

Non-interest income accounted for 44.3% of retail banks’ total operating income, remaining largely stable. Although fee and commission income fell by 11.3%, dividend income and foreign exchange and derivative portfolio income rose by 123.5% and 39.7% respectively.

# 貨幣穩定

儘管外圍環境波動及美元息率上升，港元匯率在2016年仍然保持穩定。香港貨幣市場亦繼續運作暢順，銀行同業流動資金充裕。聯繫匯率制度繼續展現高度承受衝擊的能力，是香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石。

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：
- 負債證明書（為3間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣
- 銀行在金管局所持結算戶口的結餘總額（即總結餘）
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

# 2016年回顧

# 匯率穩定

港元匯率在2016年首兩個月略有波動後，於年內餘下時間一直窄幅徘徊。港元在2016年初兌美元顯著轉弱，由1月4日的7.7510降至1月20日的7.8196（圖1）。港元匯率轉弱符合聯繫匯率制度的正常運作，反映美國在2015年12月加息後港元與美元的負息差擴濶。此外，其他市場相關因素，包括香港股市出現拋售、內地及香港經濟前景不及以前樂觀、人民幣匯率波動增加，以及亞洲貨幣普遍疲弱，均導致港元需求減弱。受到市場氣氛改善支持，港元匯率在2月略為轉強，並自3月起一直在7.753至7.776之間窄幅徘徊，即使英國脫歐公投及美國總統選舉引發市場波動亦未受影響。由於市場預期美國會在夏季加息，港元匯率於5月出現短暫的轉弱壓力。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2016年一直正常運作。

# 貨幣市場

香港銀行同業拆息在2016年大部分時間維持在較低水平（圖3）。香港銀行同業拆息在1、2月期間因金融市場波動加劇而面對一些上升壓力，但在3月隨着金融環境回復平靜而轉趨穩定。於第2及第3季，儘管市場關注英國脫歐公投結果以及美國貨幣市場基金改革，香港銀行同業拆息仍大致保持穩定。部分受到年底資金需求影響，以及港元拆息追回美元拆息的升幅，香港銀行同業拆息在第4季錄得較大升幅。儘管如此，短期銀行同業拆息在2016年大致維持在低於基本利率的水平。

因應美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍於12月14日（美國時間）由0.25至0.50厘上調至0.50至0.75厘，基本利率於12月15日由0.75厘上調至1.00厘。基本利率的調整是按照於2009年3月26日宣布的經修訂計算公式作出。按照該公式，基本利率定於美國聯邦基金利率目標範圍下限加50基點的水平，或隔夜與1個月香港銀行同業拆息的5天移動平均數的平均值水平，兩者以較高者為準。

# 聯繫匯率制度

儘管經歷多次區內以至全球金融危機，聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）過去數十年來一直是香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石。2016年初市場波動加劇，再度引起有關港元轉弱及情況有如亞洲金融危機時期的評論。為增進各界對聯匯制度的認識，金管局向公眾闡釋聯匯制度的技術細節，並指出香港金融體系有能力抵禦衝擊。政府亦重申堅決維持聯匯制度。外匯及貨幣市場穩定，進一步鞏固公眾對政府維持聯匯制度的決心以及港元作為支付及保值貨幣的信心。國際貨幣基金組織在與香港進行年度第四條磋商時，明確表示聯匯制度是最適合香港的貨幣制度，指出香港靈活的經濟結構、充裕的財政及儲備緩衝、以及穩健有效的金融監管是聯匯制度的後盾。

鑑於穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用，金管局繼續密切監察銀行的信用、流動性及利率風險管理以及壓力測試結果，並加強對銀行個人、企業及內地相關貸款的監管，以確保銀行體系具備應付衝擊的能力。面對美國貨幣政策正常化，香港銀行同業拆息開始上升，金管局提醒市民保持警覺，並作好準備以應付可能出現的市場波動及風險。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的貨幣發行委員會負責監察和探討與香港貨幣及金融穩定有關的課題。在2016年，貨幣發行委員會探討的課題包括香港與中國內地及美國經濟增長同步性、港元貨幣外部需求及香港的金融狀況指數。貨幣發行委員會會議紀錄及金管局向其呈交的貨幣發行局制度運作報告，均載於金管局網站。

# Monetary Stability

Despite volatile external conditions and rising US interest rates, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate remained stable in 2016. Hong Kong’s monetary market also continued to operate smoothly, with ample interbank liquidity. The Linked Exchange Rate System continued to demonstrate its strong capacity to withstand shocks, underpinning Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability.

# Objectives

The primary objective of Hong Kong’s monetary policy is to maintain monetary stability, i.e. to ensure the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate, keeping it within the range of HK$7.75 to HK$7.85 per US dollar in the foreign exchange market. The monetary system primarily operates under the Currency Board System, which stipulates that the US dollar reserves held by the Exchange Fund must provide at least 100% backing to the monetary base. If the monetary base changes, the US dollar reserves must also be adjusted accordingly, matching the change in the monetary base by 100%.

The monetary base (Table 1) includes:
- Certificates of indebtedness (which fully back the banknotes issued by the three note-issuing banks)
- Government-issued notes and coins in circulation
- The total balance of banks’ settlement accounts held with the HKMA (i.e. the Aggregate Balance)
- Exchange Fund paper issued by the HKMA on behalf of the Government.

Table 1 Monetary Base

The HKMA maintains the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate through an automatic interest rate adjustment mechanism and a firm commitment to the convertibility undertaking. If market demand for the Hong Kong dollar exceeds supply, causing the market exchange rate to strengthen to HK$7.75 per US dollar (the strong-side convertibility undertaking rate), the HKMA will sell Hong Kong dollars to banks and buy US dollars, thereby increasing the Aggregate Balance and lowering Hong Kong dollar interest rates. This brings the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate back from the strong-side convertibility undertaking level to within the convertibility zone of HK$7.75 to HK$7.85. Conversely, if the supply of Hong Kong dollars exceeds demand, causing the market exchange rate to weaken to HK$7.85 per US dollar (the weak-side convertibility undertaking rate), the HKMA will buy Hong Kong dollars from banks, thereby reducing the Aggregate Balance and pushing up Hong Kong dollar interest rates. This brings the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate back from the weak-side convertibility undertaking level to within the convertibility zone.

# Review of 2016

# Exchange Rate Stability

After some fluctuations in the first two months of 2016, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate traded in a narrow range for the rest of the year. The Hong Kong dollar weakened significantly against the US dollar at the beginning of 2016, falling from 7.7510 on 4 January to 7.8196 on 20 January (Figure 1). This weakening of the Hong Kong dollar was consistent with the normal operation of the Linked Exchange Rate System, reflecting the widening negative interest rate differential between the Hong Kong dollar and the US dollar after the US raised interest rates in December 2015. In addition, other market-related factors contributed to weaker demand for the Hong Kong dollar, including a sell-off in the Hong Kong stock market, less optimistic economic prospects for the Mainland and Hong Kong, increased volatility in the renminbi exchange rate, and general weakness in Asian currencies. Supported by an improvement in market sentiment, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate strengthened slightly in February and traded in a narrow range of 7.753 to 7.776 from March onwards, unaffected even by market volatility triggered by the Brexit referendum and the US presidential election. The Hong Kong dollar came under brief weakening pressure in May as the market expected the US to raise interest rates in the summer. Overall, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange market operated normally in 2016.

# Monetary Market

Hong Kong interbank offered rates (HIBORs) remained at relatively low levels for most of 2016 (Figure 3). HIBORs faced some upward pressure in January and February due to heightened volatility in financial markets, but stabilised in March as financial conditions calmed. In the second and third quarters, despite market concerns about the outcome of the Brexit referendum and reforms to US money market funds, HIBORs remained largely stable. HIBORs recorded a larger increase in the fourth quarter, partly due to year-end funding demand and the catch-up of Hong Kong interbank rates with the rise in US interbank rates. Nevertheless, short-term interbank rates remained generally below the Base Rate in 2016.

In response to the upward adjustment of the target range for the US Federal Funds Rate from 0.25–0.50% to 0.50–0.75% on 14 December (US time), the Base Rate was raised from 0.75% to 1.00% on 15 December. This adjustment was made in accordance with the revised formula announced on 26 March 2009. Under this formula, the Base Rate is set at either 50 basis points above the lower end of the target range for the US Federal Funds Rate or the average of the five-day moving averages of the overnight and one-month HIBORs, whichever is higher.

Figure 3 Hong Kong interbank offered rates in 2016

Hong Kong dollar forward points recorded a substantial premium in January, broadly following the movement of the interest rate differential between the Hong Kong dollar and the US dollar, and partly reflecting investors’ demand for currency hedging of their Hong Kong equity portfolios (Figure 4). The forward premium narrowed in February. As market conditions stabilised, Hong Kong dollar forward points remained largely stable between March and November, before rising again in December due to a narrowing of the interest rate differential between the Hong Kong dollar and the US dollar. Overall, the Hong Kong monetary market operated smoothly, with ample interbank liquidity. Discount window lending was not active in 2016, involving only HK$5.3 billion.

# Linked Exchange Rate System

Despite experiencing several regional and global financial crises, the Linked Exchange Rate System (LERS) has been the cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability over the past few decades. Heightened market volatility at the beginning of 2016 once again triggered comments about the weakening of the Hong Kong dollar and comparisons with the Asian financial crisis. To enhance public understanding of the LERS, the HKMA explained its technical details to the public and emphasised that Hong Kong’s financial system was capable of withstanding shocks. The Government also reiterated its commitment to maintaining the LERS. The stability of the foreign exchange and monetary markets further reinforced public confidence in the Government’s determination to maintain the LERS and in the Hong Kong dollar as a medium for payment and store of value. In its annual Article IV Consultation with Hong Kong, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) explicitly stated that the LERS was the most suitable monetary system for Hong Kong, noting that Hong Kong’s flexible economic structure, ample fiscal and reserve buffers, and robust and effective financial regulation were the underpinnings of the LERS.

Figure 4 US dollar/Hong Kong dollar forward points in 2016

Given that a robust banking system is critical to the normal operation of the LERS, the HKMA continued to closely monitor banks’ credit, liquidity and interest rate risk management, as well as stress-test results, and strengthened supervision of banks’ personal, corporate and Mainland-related lending to ensure that the banking system was capable of withstanding shocks. As Hong Kong interbank rates began to rise in response to the normalisation of US monetary policy, the HKMA reminded the public to remain vigilant and prepare for potential market volatility and risks.

To enhance the transparency of the Currency Board Account, part of the assets of the Exchange Fund have been designated to back the monetary base since October 1998. The backing ratio (i.e. the ratio of backing assets to the monetary base) fluctuated narrowly between 106.3% and 107.5% in 2016, without touching the upper or lower limit. The ratio stood at 106.7% on 31 December 2016 (Figure 5). Under the LERS, although certain assets of the Exchange Fund have been designated as the backing portfolio, all assets of the Exchange Fund can be used to support the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate. The Exchange Fund’s substantial financial resources provide a strong buffer for Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability in the face of unexpected shocks.

The Currency Board Sub-Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee (eFAC) is responsible for monitoring and studying issues related to Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability. The minutes of the Sub-Committee’s meetings and the HKMA’s reports to it on the operation of the Currency Board System are available on the HKMA website.

The Hong Kong Institute for Monetary Research (HKIMR) continued to support research work in the areas of monetary policy, banking and finance. In 2016, the Institute invited 18 scholars to visit and published 20 working papers.

# 監管工作概覽

金管局在2016年共進行188次非現場審查，涵蓋範圍廣泛，包括認可機構的CAMEL評級、企業管治、業務運作及風險管理。金管局加強與認可機構董事局的聯繫，以強化銀行業的風險管治及企業文化。除與董事局或董事局委員會舉行會議外，亦另行與獨立非執行董事（獨立非執董）會面，就企業文化及風險管治事宜交換意見。金管局亦與認可機構及其外聘審計師舉行三方聯席會議。此外，金管局就認可機構的薪酬制度是否有助促進有效的風險管理進行評估。

在資本充足水平方面，金管局審視認可機構的資本計劃，包括其未來數年的資本目標，以便就2019年全面實施《巴塞爾協定三》緩衝資本作好準備。認可機構的償付能力壓力測試亦因應當前宏觀經濟環境作出改進。金管局又審慎評估各主要零售銀行的恢復計劃，並就需要改善的環節提出意見。

除了非現場審查工作外，金管局繼續以專題評估配合定期現場審查，而專題評估主要適用於被評定為較高風險的範疇。這種監管方法讓金管局更有效地調配監管資源，以應對認可機構所面對的各項新增及主要風險。金管局在2016年共進行377次現場審查及專題評估。這些審查與評估的重點仍是信用風險管理與監控，尤其涉及內地相關業務的信用風險；另一個重點是打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集監控措施。金管局又增加對流動性風險、業務操作風險及科技風險管理的現場審查及專題評估次數。年內專項審查小組亦對認可機構的證券、投資產品、保險及強制性公積金（強積金）相關業務進行現場審查。

# 信貸增長及資產質素

銀行貸款在2016年增長溫和。未償還貸款總額全年增加6.5%；2015年的增幅則為3.5%（表2）。由於客戶存款的增幅超過銀行貸款的增幅，整體貸存比率由2015年底的70.1%降至2016年底的68.4%。

表 2 貸款及墊款的增長

內地相關貸款總額在2016年底增加7%至35,640億港元（表3），其中包括在香港註冊的銀行設於內地的附屬公司入帳的5,450億港元貸款。

銀行業的資產質素在2016年維持穩健。儘管零售銀行的特定分類貸款比率由2015年底的0.69%微升至2016年底的0.72%，但仍遠低於2000年以來的長期平均水平2.4%。同期，整體銀行業的特定分類貸款比率由0.73%上升至0.85%。年內銀行業的內地相關貸款的資產質素呈相若走勢；同期，零售銀行這些貸款的特定分類貸款比率由0.78%微升至0.82%，整體銀行業的相關比率亦由一年前的0.77%微升至0.80%。

金管局投入大量監管資源，以確保認可機構繼續採用審慎的信貸審批標準，並維持有效的貸款分類及撥備制度。金管局在監管過程中亦特別關注認可機構對中國內地民營企業的風險承擔持續增加，以及為增加收益而投資於債務證券所引起的信用風險。此外，金管局就認可機構分銷高風險投資產品的信用風險管理進行專題評估。

# 業務操作及科技風險的監管

與其他國際金融中心一樣，香港面對的網絡威脅與日俱增。金管局於2016年接到認可機構通報發現未經授權股票交易及試圖入侵其支付系統的個案，並隨即採取行動應對這些攻擊造成的風險。金管局發出電子銀行服務提示，提醒公眾慎防網上股票交易騙案，並建議公眾採取預防措施。金管局又向認可機構發出通告，就進一步加強網上銀行服務監控可採取的保安措施提供指引。有關試圖入侵銀行支付系統的個案，金管局在香港首次發現相關個案時已提醒認可機構留意這類騙案，並在警方協助下說明這類騙案的犯案手法，以及要求認可機構在加強支付操作的監控措施時須顧及有關手法。

為進一步提升銀行體系應對網絡風險的能力，金管局於2016年5月推出網絡防衛計劃。此計劃由三項支柱組成，即網絡防衛評估框架、專業培訓計劃及網絡風險資訊共享平台（詳見「香港的國際金融中心地位」一章「金融科技促進辦公室」部分）。金管局在12月向認可機構發出通告，列載網絡防衛評估框架的實施時間表。

金融科技在銀行業的應用於2016年長足發展，多間認可機構推出新的金融科技產品，其中個人小額支付服務、非接觸式流動支付及生物認證這幾個範疇的發展尤為顯著。金管局在9月推出「金融科技監管沙盒」，讓認可機構能在受控環境中就其金融科技項目先作試行，而無需完全符合金管局的監管規定。有關安排讓認可機構在正式推出金融科技服務前，可及早收集真實數據及用戶意見，以便作出適當修改。截至2016年底，共有6項使用金融科技監管沙盒的申請獲批，有關的新金融科技產品涉及生物認證、證券交易及用於按揭估值的區塊鏈。金管局又在11月上調無需雙重認證的網上銀行個人小額支付服務的交易上限至每個帳戶每日5,000港元，以應付日益增加的簡便個人支付服務需求。

2016年發生多宗與物業相關的騙案，當中涉及騙徒假扮業主，試圖藉申請按揭貸款或出售有關物業謀取利益。雖然這些騙案並不涉及認可機構，但金管局仍與警方及香港銀行公會（銀行公會）緊密合作，就偵測及防止這些騙案在銀行業內發生向認可機構提供指引。年內金管局出版兩期《操作事故通訊》，與業界分享從認可機構發生過的操作事故中汲取的教訓。金管局亦對認可機構的業務操作風險管理制度、詐騙管理方法、信託╱託管業務操作及防範違規或未經授權交易活動的風險管理及監控措施進行現場審查及專題評估。

# 財資業務及流動性風險的監管

2016年發生數宗重大政治事件，引致金融市場在年內多次大幅波動。與此同時，美國利率繼續緩慢地正常化，聯邦公開市場委員會於12月決定調高聯邦基金利率，是全球金融危機以來的第二次。為應對這些政治事件作好準備，金管局與境外監管機構繼續保持緊密聯繫，並評估事件對香港銀行體系的影響，以及要求銀行保持警覺並加強其風險管理以應對不利的市場發展。

在流動性風險管理方面，金管局進行額外的流動性壓力測試，以評估銀行體系應對可能發生的嚴峻壓力情境的能力，並對認可機構作出跟進，以加強其應對能力。金管局在2015年針對利率風險管理進行一輪現場審查後，再進行額外的現場審查，以評估認可機構的市場風險管理，並要求在監控方面存有不足的認可機構作出糾正。

# 打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集活動

金管局的風險為本打擊洗錢監管包括現場審查及非現場審查（包括就特定事件與認可機構進行的監管聯繫），主要針對洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集風險較高的範疇。審查內容涵蓋認可機構對洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集風險的評估、風險為本方法的落實情況，以及交易監察與制裁合規的制度和程序。金管局的專項監管人員在2016年共進行17次現場審查及30次非現場審查。

在政策發展方面，金管局優先處理某些行業及人士在開立銀行帳戶方面遇到困難的情況，並發出指引與「常見問題」，以釐清若干客戶盡職審查的規定，以及金管局就風險為本方法的監管期望。與此同時，金管局繼續與業內公會緊密合作，發出指引以協助認可機構處理某些範疇的風險，例如貿易相關的洗錢活動。

# Banking Stability

Despite increased global market risks and volatility, Hong Kong’s banking system remained robust in 2016. During the year, the HKMA strengthened its oversight of authorised institutions’ risk governance frameworks and the effectiveness of their credit and liquidity risk management systems. In light of the growing frequency of cyberattacks, the HKMA also enhanced its supervision of authorised institutions’ technology risk management. To further the HKMA’s goal of combating financial crime, the effectiveness of authorised institutions’ anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing controls remained a key focus of the HKMA’s supervision. In terms of regulating the conduct of authorised institutions, the HKMA took concrete actions to promote a customer-centric culture and financial inclusion, and to address the difficulties faced by overseas SMEs and start-up companies in opening and maintaining bank accounts in Hong Kong. The HKMA also strengthened its supervision of authorised institutions’ sales practices for investment and insurance products to further enhance customer protection.

In terms of regulatory policy, the HKMA made significant progress in preparing Hong Kong for the implementation of international supervisory and accounting standards, including the Net Stable Funding Ratio, large exposure limits, International Financial Reporting Standard 9 and the resolution framework under the Financial Institutions (Resolution) Ordinance.

# 2016 Review

# Overview of supervisory work

In 2016, the HKMA conducted 188 off-site reviews, covering a wide range of areas including authorised institutions’ CAMEL ratings, corporate governance, business operations and risk management. The HKMA strengthened its communication with authorised institutions’ boards of directors to enhance risk governance and corporate culture in the banking sector. In addition to meetings with the board or board committees, separate meetings were held with independent non-executive directors to exchange views on corporate culture and risk governance. The HKMA also held tripartite meetings with authorised institutions and their external auditors. Furthermore, the HKMA assessed whether authorised institutions’ remuneration systems were conducive to effective risk management.

In terms of capital adequacy, the HKMA reviewed authorised institutions’ capital plans, including their capital targets for the next few years, in preparation for the full implementation of Basel III capital buffers in 2019. Authorised institutions’ solvency stress testing programme was also improved to reflect the current macroeconomic environment. The HKMA also prudently assessed the recovery plans of major retail banks and provided comments on areas that needed improvement.

In addition to off-site reviews, the HKMA continued to conduct thematic reviews in conjunction with regular on-site examinations, with thematic reviews mainly applicable to areas assessed as higher risk. This supervisory approach enabled the HKMA to allocate supervisory resources more effectively to address new and major risks faced by authorised institutions. In 2016, the HKMA conducted 377 on-site examinations and thematic reviews. The focus of these examinations and reviews remained on credit risk management and monitoring, particularly credit risks associated with Mainland-related business; another focus was on anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing controls. The HKMA also increased the number of on-site examinations and thematic reviews on liquidity risk, operational risk and technology risk management. During the year, a special inspection team also conducted on-site examinations of authorised institutions’ securities, investment products, insurance and Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF)-related businesses.

Table 1 provides a summary of the HKMA’s supervisory work in 2016.

# Supervision of credit risk

# Credit growth and asset quality

Bank lending grew moderately in 2016. Total outstanding loans increased by 6.5% over the year; the increase in 2015 was 3.5% (Table 2). As customer deposits grew faster than bank loans, the overall loan-to-deposit ratio fell from 70.1% at the end of 2015 to 68.4% at the end of 2016.

Table 2 Growth in loans and advances

Total Mainland-related loans increased by 7% to HK$3,564 billion at the end of 2016 (Table 3), including HK$545 billion in loans booked by Mainland subsidiaries of banks incorporated in Hong Kong.

The asset quality of the banking sector remained sound in 2016. Although the classified loan ratio for retail banks edged up slightly from 0.69% at the end of 2015 to 0.72% at the end of 2016, it was still far below the long-term average of 2.4% since 2000. Over the same period, the classified loan ratio for the banking sector as a whole rose from 0.73% to 0.85%. The asset quality of Mainland-related loans of the banking sector followed a similar trend during the year; over the same period, the classified loan ratio for these loans of retail banks edged up slightly from 0.78% to 0.82%, while the corresponding ratio for the banking sector as a whole also edged up slightly from 0.77% a year earlier to 0.80%.

The HKMA devoted substantial supervisory resources to ensuring that authorised institutions continued to adopt prudent credit approval standards and maintain effective loan classification and provisioning systems. In the course of its supervision, the HKMA also paid particular attention to authorised institutions’ increasing risk exposure to privately owned enterprises in Mainland China and the credit risks arising from investment in debt securities for yield enhancement. In addition, the HKMA conducted thematic reviews on authorised institutions’ credit risk management in distributing high-risk investment products.

# Mortgage loans

The HKMA continued to closely monitor authorised institutions’ property lending business. Residential property prices began to adjust in September 2015, but then rose again in March 2016, increasing by 8% over the year as a whole. The average loan-to-value ratio for new residential mortgage loans fell from 64% in September 2009, before the HKMA introduced the first round of countercyclical prudential measures for property loans, to 51% in December 2016. The average debt-servicing ratio for new residential mortgage loans also fell from 41% in August 2010, when the debt-servicing ratio cap was first introduced, to 34% in December 2016 (Chart 1).

Chart 1 Average loan-to-value ratio and debt-servicing ratio for new residential mortgage loans
The HKMA introduced a debt-servicing ratio cap before the first round of countercyclical measures for property loans

Under the HKMA’s seventh round of countercyclical measures introduced in February 2015, authorised institutions using the Internal Ratings-Based (IRB) approach to calculate credit risk capital requirements were required to extend the application of the 15% risk-weight floor from new mortgage loans to the entire residential mortgage loan portfolio. This requirement took effect in June 2016.

During the year, more property developers provided mortgage loans directly to property buyers, with loan-to-value ratios often higher than the level permitted under the HKMA’s prudential requirements for authorised institutions. The HKMA closely monitored these developments and maintained regular communication with authorised institutions to assess whether banks continued to manage their risk exposure to property developers effectively. In addition, at the HKMA’s request, the Land Registry agreed to provide an e-Alert service to authorised institutions. Authorised institutions using this service would receive an electronic alert message from the Land Registry when other mortgage documents relating to a property mortgaged to them were submitted to the Land Registry for registration. This service would help address the situation where a mortgage borrower obtained additional mortgage financing for the same property without prior consent from the mortgaging authorised institution. The Land Registry launched the e-Alert service in the first quarter of 2017.

# Supervision of operational and technology risks

Like other international financial centres, Hong Kong faces increasing cyber threats. In 2016, the HKMA received reports from authorised institutions about unauthorised stock trading and attempted hacking of their payment systems, and took immediate action to address the risks posed by these attacks. The HKMA issued an e-banking services alert to remind the public to beware of online stock trading scams and to suggest preventive measures. The HKMA also issued a circular to authorised institutions providing guidance on further security measures that could be taken to enhance monitoring of online banking services. In relation to attempted hacking of bank payment systems, the HKMA alerted authorised institutions to this type of scam when it first discovered such cases in Hong Kong, and, with the assistance of the police, explained the modus operandi of such scams and required authorised institutions to take these into account when enhancing their monitoring of payment operations.

To further enhance the banking sector’s cyber resilience, the HKMA launched a Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative in May 2016. The initiative comprises three pillars, namely a Cyber Resilience Assessment Framework, a professional training programme and a Cyber Intelligence Sharing Platform (see the section on the “Fintech Facilitation Office” in the chapter on “Hong Kong’s International Financial Centre Status”). In December, the HKMA issued a circular to authorised institutions setting out the implementation timetable for the Cyber Resilience Assessment Framework.

Fintech applications in the banking sector made significant progress in 2016, with many authorised institutions launching new fintech products, particularly in the areas of person-to-person small-value payment services, contactless mobile payments and biometric authentication. In September, the HKMA launched a Fintech Supervisory Sandbox to allow authorised institutions to pilot their fintech projects in a controlled environment without having to fully comply with the HKMA’s supervisory requirements. This arrangement enabled authorised institutions to collect real data and user feedback at an early stage before formally launching fintech services, so that appropriate modifications could be made. As at the end of 2016, six applications to use the Fintech Supervisory Sandbox had been approved, involving new fintech products relating to biometric authentication, securities trading and blockchain for mortgage valuation. In November, the HKMA raised the transaction limit for person-to-person small-value payment services conducted through online banking without two-factor authentication to HK$5,000 per account per day to meet the growing demand for convenient person-to-person payment services.

In 2016, there were a number of property-related scams involving fraudsters impersonating property owners and attempting to profit by applying for mortgage loans or selling the properties concerned. Although these scams did not involve authorised institutions, the HKMA worked closely with the police and the Hong Kong Association of Banks to provide guidance to authorised institutions on detecting and preventing such scams in the banking sector. During the year, the HKMA published two issues of the Operational Incidents Watch to share with the industry lessons learned from operational incidents that had occurred at authorised institutions. The HKMA also conducted on-site examinations and thematic reviews of authorised institutions’ operational risk management systems, fraud management methods, trustee/custodian operations and risk management and monitoring measures to prevent rogue or unauthorised trading activities.

# Supervision of treasury activities and liquidity risk

A number of major political events occurred in 2016, causing significant volatility in financial markets during the year. At the same time, US interest rates continued their gradual normalisation, with the Federal Open Market Committee deciding in December to raise the Federal Funds Rate for the second time since the global financial crisis. To prepare for these political events, the HKMA maintained close contact with overseas regulators and assessed the impact of the events on Hong Kong’s banking system, and required banks to remain vigilant and strengthen their risk management to cope with adverse market developments.

In terms of liquidity risk management, the HKMA conducted additional liquidity stress tests to assess the banking sector’s ability to cope with potentially severe stress scenarios and followed up with authorised institutions to enhance their coping ability. Following a round of on-site examinations on interest rate risk management in 2015, the HKMA conducted additional on-site examinations to assess authorised institutions’ market risk management and required authorised institutions with deficiencies in monitoring to make corrections.

# Prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing

The HKMA’s risk-based anti-money laundering supervision includes on-site and off-site reviews (including regulatory liaison with authorised institutions on specific cases), focusing mainly on areas with higher risks of money laundering and terrorist financing. The reviews cover authorised institutions’ assessment of money laundering and terrorist financing risks, implementation of a risk-based approach, and systems and procedures for transaction monitoring and sanctions compliance. In 2016, the HKMA’s specialist supervisory staff conducted 17 on-site examinations and 30 off-site reviews.

In terms of policy development, the HKMA gave priority to addressing the difficulties faced by certain industries and individuals in opening bank accounts, and issued guidance and “frequently asked questions” to clarify certain customer due diligence requirements and the HKMA’s supervisory expectations in relation to the risk-based approach. At the same time, the HKMA continued to work closely with industry associations to issue guidance to help authorised institutions address risks in certain areas, such as trade-based money laundering.

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

香港維持其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位。去年的稅務修訂有助營造有利環境，吸引跨國公司在港設立企業財資中心。為發展香港成為基建融資中心與金融科技樞紐，金管局在年內成立基建融資促進辦公室及金融科技促進辦公室。年內金管局向儲值支付工具發行人批出13個牌照。香港穩健的財政表現及龐大的對外資產淨值，繼續獲得信貸評級機構確認，其中標準普爾維持對香港AAA的評級。

# 概覽

受到環球金融市場波動及人民幣匯率前景不確定性影響，2016年全球離岸人民幣業務有所放緩。儘管如此，香港維持其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位，處理全球約七成人民幣支付交易。深港股票市場交易互聯互通機制「深港通」於12月推出，標誌着內地資本帳開放的另一里程碑，並且是提升香港的國際金融中心地位的重要一步。金管局亦透過擴大對市場的人民幣流動性支援及推出措施增加人民幣市場流動性的透明度，強化金融基建。

金管局於7月成立基建融資促進辦公室(IFFO)，透過匯聚主要持份者促進基建發展，並發展香港成為基建融資中心。截至2017年1月底，已有超過60間機構加入IFFO成為合作夥伴。年內金管局亦成功推動法例修訂的通過，以消除稅務不對稱及提供稅務優惠，鼓勵跨國及內地公司在香港設立企業財資中心，為金融及專業服務行業帶來更多商機。在香港駐設業務的機構投資者數目亦逐漸增加，其中作為全球第三大主權基金的阿布扎比投資局於10月宣布在香港成立海外辦事處，是該機構唯一設於阿布扎比以外的辦事處。

國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）在去年的第四條磋商討論中對我們致力鞏固香港作為國際金融中心的地位給予正面評價。年內金管局積極參與國際討論，致力推進全球與區內金融穩定。金管局亦與國際信貸評級機構保持緊密溝通，有關工作有助香港的信貸評級在2016年獲得主要信貸評級機構確認。

香港金融基建的安全有效運作與持續發展，對鞏固香港作為國際金融中心及全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的競爭力發揮重要作用。處理銀行同業交易的4個即時支付結算(RTGS)系統及債務工具中央結算系統（CMU系統）在2016年達到100%的系統可供使用率，高於99.95%的目標水平。

金管局在2016年進一步加強香港的零售支付金融基建。年內根據2016年11月全面生效的《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）批出總共13個儲值支付工具牌照。電子支票服務涵蓋範圍亦已擴展至香港和廣東省（包括深圳）之間的跨境支付。

為促進香港金融科技的發展，金管局於3月成立金融科技促進辦公室。年內實施的多項重要措施均取得理想進展。

金管局推出一系列措施加強銀行業軟實力，包括(i)推出提升董事專業能力計劃；(ii)訂立整體業界的銀行從業員專業資歷架構；及(iii)推行消費者教育計劃。

# 2016年回顧

# 離岸人民幣業務

2016年環球金融市場波動及人民幣匯率前景不確定性令全球離岸人民幣業務有所放緩。截至年底，香港人民幣客戶存款及存款證餘額合共為6,251億元人民幣，較上年減少38%（圖1）。年內離岸人民幣債券發行量降至528億元人民幣，經香港銀行處理的人民幣貿易結算額亦降至45,421億元人民幣。另一方面，香港銀行截至年底的人民幣貸款餘額為2,948億元人民幣，與上年相若（圖2）。人民幣RTGS系統的交易額維持於高位，於2016年平均每日處理的交易額為8,636億元人民幣。由此可見，儘管人民幣資金池有所縮減，但仍繼續支持大量人民幣金融中介活動在香港進行。根據環球銀行金融電信協會(SWIFT)統計數字，2016年香港處理約七成人民幣支付交易，足以證明香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位。

圖1 人民幣客戶存款及存款證

圖2 人民幣融資活動

年內金管局與內地有關當局緊密合作爭取更大政策空間，推展香港人民幣業務。年內推出多項新措施，包括進一步加大內地銀行間債券市場及外匯市場對外開放，以及在12月推出「深港通」。因應跨境投資渠道及市場對流動性管理需求增加，金管局擴大人民幣流動資金安排。於10月，金管局將一級流動性提供行的數目由7間增加至9間，有關計劃的總額度亦由140億元人民幣增加至180億元人民幣。金管局人民幣流動資金安排使用情況的透明度亦提高，有助參加行更有效管理流動資金。

在3月公布的國家「十三五」規劃再次肯定香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位，顯示中央政府支持香港進一步發展離岸人民幣業務。

與此同時，金管局繼續加強與其他經濟體的合作，發展離岸人民幣業務。金管局亦積極參加各類活動，推廣香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐及內地「走出去策略跳板的主要角色，包括參與業界組織及私營機構舉辦的本地活動，以及在中國內地、德國、哈薩克斯坦和英國等地的境外活動。

# 內地與香港關於建立更緊密經貿關係的安排

在《內地與香港關於建立更緊密經貿關係的安排》框架下有關內地與香港基本實現服務貿易自由化的新協議，於2015年簽署。金管局繼續密切留意現行安排下的措施的實施情況，並與政府當局合作探討進步擴大內地市場對香港金融業的開放及便利措施。

# 基建融資促進辦公室(IFFO)

# IFFO的使命

IFFO的使命是透過匯聚主要持份者，共同促進基建投融資。IFFO的職能是：
- 提供一個資訊交流和經驗分享的平台；
- 提升基建投融資方面的技能和知識；
- 推廣市場及產品發展；
- 及促進基建投融資活動。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（左七）於IFFO啟動儀式上聯同其他嘉賓祝酒。

金管局於7月成立IFFO，其使命是透過匯聚主要持份者共同促進基建投融資。截至2017年1月底，已有超過60間來自中國內地、香港及海外的機構加入IFFO成為合作夥伴，當中包括多邊金融機構及發展銀行、公營機構投資者、私營機構投資者、資產管理公司、銀行、保險公司、基建項目發展及營運機構、專業服務公司及國際貿易協會（表1）。

IFFO自成立以來取得良好進展。為致力提升技能，IFFO於10月聯同世界銀行集團旗下國際金融公司和瀚亞投資主辦行政人員工作坊，主題為「私營資金參與新興市場基建項目的投融資」。該工作坊獲得參與者非常正面的回應，有助增長知識及建立網絡。IFFO另於11月舉辦高層研討會，並邀請亞洲基礎設施投資銀行行長金立群先生主講及分享基建項目規劃、營運與管理的經驗。於7月，IFFO分別與國際金融公司及全球基礎設施中心簽訂《諒解備忘錄》，建立合作框架。另於12月分別與國家開發銀行及中國進出口銀行簽訂《諒解備忘錄》，透過IFFO平台促進該兩間銀行的基建項目融資。這些活動有助加強香港作為基建融資中心的地位及國際形象。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（前左）與國際金融公司執行副總裁兼首席執行官菲利普• 勒奧魯先生（前右）簽署《諒解備忘錄》，促成兩者合作利用IFFO平台，為區內基建投融資營造更有效率及有利的市場環境。

金管局總裁陳德霖先生（前左）與全球基礎設施中心首席執行官Chris Heathcote先生（前右）簽署《諒解備忘錄》，建立策略性合作框架，促進基建項目融資。

# 企業財資中心

為進一步吸引跨國公司在香港設立企業財資中心，金管局與政府當局合作，營造一個對企業財資中心有利的稅務環境。具體上，《2016年稅務（修訂）（第2號）條例》（《修訂條例》）於6月通過，容許企業在符合指明條件下，在計算利得稅時可獲扣減經營集團內部融資業務的利息支出，以及就合資格企業財資中心指明財資業務的利潤，寬減利得稅百分之五十（即降至8.25%）。表2簡載《修訂條例》部分要點：

除立法工作外，金管局亦積極向跨國和內地企業推廣在香港設立企業財資中心的優勢。截至年底，金管局已接觸近400間公司、金融機構及行業組織。金管局亦於11月與香港中國企業協會簽署《諒解備忘錄》，協助香港的中資企業進一步了解及更多利用我們的企業財資中心平台。

# 推廣資產管理業務

金管局繼續致力推廣香港作為資產管理中心。根據證券及期貨事務監察委員會（證監會），從事資產管理的持牌法團數目於2016年底為1,300間，按年增加近15%。根據《亞洲創業投資期刊》，2016年在香港的私募基金公司（包括證監會持牌法團及非證監會持牌法團）數目亦增加4.6%，至431間。迄今全球百大資產管理公司中有接近70間，以及內地二十大互惠基金公司中的大多數，已在香港設有業務或相聯公司。在香港駐設業務的機構投資者數目亦逐漸增加，其中作為全球第三大主權基金的阿布扎比投資局於10月宣布在香港成立海外辦事處，是該機構於阿布扎比以外設立的唯一辦事處。

# 引入開放式基金型公司結構

# 伊斯蘭金融

金管局繼續致力增加市場對伊斯蘭金融的認識和了解，包括聯同業界公會舉辦及參與伊斯蘭金融研討會及講座，並與市場參與者分享有關發行伊斯蘭債券的經驗，鼓勵它們使用香港的平台。繼成功發行上兩批伊斯蘭債券後，金管局與政府一直緊密合作，在市場條件合適時推出第三批伊斯蘭債券。
