# Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre

Hong Kong has maintained its position as a global offshore renminbi business hub. Last year’s tax reforms helped create a favourable environment to attract multinational corporations to establish corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong. To develop Hong Kong into an infrastructure financing hub and a financial technology centre, the HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office and the Fintech Facilitation Office during the year. During the year, the HKMA granted 13 licences to issuers of stored value facilities. Hong Kong’s robust fiscal performance and substantial net external assets continued to be recognised by credit rating agencies, with Standard & Poor’s maintaining Hong Kong’s triple-A rating.

# Overview

Global offshore renminbi business slowed in 2016 due to volatility in global financial markets and uncertainty over the renminbi exchange rate outlook. Nevertheless, Hong Kong maintained its position as a global offshore renminbi business hub, handling around 70% of global renminbi payment transactions. The Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect, a stock market trading link between Shenzhen and Hong Kong, was launched in December, marking another milestone in the opening up of mainland China’s capital account and an important step in enhancing Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre. The HKMA also strengthened financial infrastructure by expanding renminbi liquidity support to the market and introducing measures to increase the transparency of renminbi market liquidity.

In July, the HKMA established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) to promote infrastructure development by bringing together key stakeholders and to develop Hong Kong into an infrastructure financing hub. As at the end of January 2017, more than 60 institutions had joined IFFO as partners. During the year, the HKMA also successfully promoted the passage of legislative amendments to eliminate tax asymmetry and provide tax incentives to encourage multinational and mainland companies to establish corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong, thereby creating more business opportunities for the financial and professional services industries. The number of institutional investors operating in Hong Kong has also been gradually increasing. In October, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, the world’s third largest sovereign wealth fund, announced the establishment of an overseas office in Hong Kong, its only office outside Abu Dhabi.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) gave a positive assessment of our efforts to consolidate Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre during last year’s Article IV Consultation discussions. During the year, the HKMA actively participated in international discussions to promote global and regional financial stability. The HKMA also maintained close communication with international credit rating agencies, which helped Hong Kong’s credit ratings to be affirmed by major credit rating agencies in 2016.

The safe, efficient operation and continued development of Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure play an important role in consolidating Hong Kong’s competitiveness as an international financial centre and a global offshore renminbi business hub. The four real-time gross settlement (RTGS) systems for processing interbank transactions and the Central Moneymarkets Unit (CMU) system achieved a system availability rate of 100% in 2016, exceeding the target level of 99.95%.

The HKMA further strengthened Hong Kong’s retail payment financial infrastructure in 2016. During the year, a total of 13 stored value facility licences were granted under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (PSSVFO), which came into full effect in November 2016. The coverage of e-cheque services has also been extended to cross-border payments between Hong Kong and Guangdong Province (including Shenzhen).

To promote the development of financial technology in Hong Kong, the HKMA established the Fintech Facilitation Office in March. A number of important measures implemented during the year have made good progress.

The HKMA introduced a series of measures to strengthen the soft power of the banking sector, including (i) launching a director professional development programme; (ii) establishing a competency framework for banking practitioners across the industry; and (iii) implementing a consumer education programme.

# Review of 2016

# Offshore renminbi business

Global offshore renminbi business slowed in 2016 due to volatility in global financial markets and uncertainty over the renminbi exchange rate outlook. As at the end of 2016, the combined balance of renminbi customer deposits and certificates of deposit in Hong Kong was RMB6,251 billion, down 38% from the previous year (Figure 1). During the year, offshore renminbi bond issuance fell to RMB528 billion, and renminbi trade settlement processed through Hong Kong banks also fell to RMB45,421 billion. On the other hand, renminbi loans outstanding at Hong Kong banks as at the end of 2016 were RMB2,948 billion, similar to the previous year (Figure 2). Transaction volume in the renminbi RTGS system remained high, with an average daily transaction volume of RMB8,636 billion in 2016. This shows that despite a shrinking renminbi liquidity pool, a large volume of renminbi financial intermediation activities continued to be supported in Hong Kong. According to statistics from the Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT), Hong Kong handled around 70% of renminbi payment activities globally in 2016, which is testament to Hong Kong’s position as a global offshore renminbi business hub.

Figure 2 Renminbi financing activities

During the year, the HKMA worked closely with relevant mainland authorities to seek greater policy flexibility to promote renminbi business in Hong Kong. A number of new measures were introduced during the year, including further opening up of mainland China’s onshore interbank bond and foreign exchange markets, and the launch of Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect in December. In response to increased demand for cross-border investment channels and liquidity management, the HKMA expanded its renminbi liquidity facility. In October, the HKMA increased the number of primary liquidity providers from seven to nine, and the total size of the facility was increased from RMB140 billion to RMB180 billion under the PLP scheme. The transparency of the HKMA’s renminbi liquidity facility utilisation was also enhanced, helping participating banks to manage liquidity more effectively.

The 13th Five-Year Plan, announced in March, reaffirmed Hong Kong’s position as a global offshore renminbi business hub, demonstrating the central government’s support for Hong Kong to further develop its offshore renminbi business.

At the same time, the HKMA continued to strengthen cooperation with other economies to develop offshore renminbi business. The HKMA also actively participated in various activities to promote Hong Kong’s role as a global offshore renminbi business hub and a key platform for mainland China’s “go global” strategy, including local events organised by industry associations and private institutions, and overseas events in mainland China, Germany, Kazakhstan and the United Kingdom.

# Arrangement between mainland China and Hong Kong on establishing a closer economic partnership

A new agreement on the basic realisation of service trade liberalisation between mainland China and Hong Kong under the framework of the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) was signed in 2015. The HKMA continues to closely monitor the implementation of measures under the current arrangement and to work with government authorities to explore further measures to expand the opening up of mainland China’s market to Hong Kong’s financial industry and to facilitate such access.

# Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO)

# Mission of IFFO

IFFO’s mission is to promote infrastructure investment and financing by bringing together key stakeholders. IFFO’s functions are:
- To provide a platform for information exchange and experience sharing;
- To enhance skills and knowledge in infrastructure investment and financing;
- To promote market and product development; and
- To facilitate infrastructure investment and financing activities.

HKMA Chief Executive Mr Norman Chan (seventh from left) toasts with other guests at the IFFO launch ceremony.

The HKMA established IFFO in July with the mission of promoting infrastructure investment and financing by bringing together key stakeholders. As at the end of January 2017, more than 60 institutions from mainland China, Hong Kong and overseas had joined IFFO as partners, including multilateral financial institutions and development banks, public institutional investors, private institutional investors, asset management companies, banks, insurance companies, infrastructure project development and operation companies, professional services firms and international business councils (Table 1).

IFFO has made good progress since its establishment. To enhance skills, IFFO co-hosted an executive workshop with the International Finance Corporation (IFC) of the World Bank Group and Eastspring Investments in October on the theme of “Private participation in infrastructure project finance in emerging markets”. The workshop received very positive feedback from participants and helped to increase knowledge and build networks. IFFO also organised a senior executive seminar in November, with Mr Jin Liqun, President of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, as the keynote speaker, sharing his experience in infrastructure project planning, operation and management. In July, IFFO signed memorandums of understanding (MOUs) with the IFC and the Global Infrastructure Hub to establish a cooperation framework. In December, IFFO also signed MOUs with the China Development Bank (CDB) and the Export-Import Bank of China to promote infrastructure project financing by the two banks through the IFFO platform. These activities helped to strengthen Hong Kong’s position and international image as an infrastructure financing hub.

HKMA Chief Executive Mr Norman Chan (front left) and Mr Philippe Le Houérou, Executive Vice President and CEO of the IFC (front right), signed a memorandum of understanding to enable both parties to cooperate in using the IFFO platform to create a more efficient and favourable market environment for infrastructure investment and financing in the region.

HKMA Chief Executive Mr Norman Chan (front left) and Mr Chris Heathcote, CEO of the Global Infrastructure Hub (front right), signed a memorandum of understanding to establish a strategic cooperation framework to promote infrastructure project financing.

HKMA Chief Executive Mr Norman Chan (left) and Mr Hu Huaibang, Chairman of the CDB, signed a memorandum of understanding to strengthen cooperation between the bank and the HKMA.

# Corporate treasury centres

To further attract multinational corporations to establish corporate treasury centres (CTCs) in Hong Kong, the HKMA worked with government authorities to create a favourable tax environment for CTCs. Specifically, the Inland Revenue (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 2016 was passed in June, allowing enterprises, subject to specified conditions, to deduct interest expenses incurred in intra-group financing business when calculating profits tax, and to enjoy a 50% profits tax concession (i.e. a reduction to 8.25%) on profits derived from specified treasury activities conducted by eligible CTCs. Table 2 summarises some key points of the revised tax regime.

In addition to legislative work, the HKMA also actively promoted the advantages of establishing CTCs in Hong Kong to multinational and mainland enterprises. As at the end of 2016, the HKMA had contacted nearly 400 companies, financial institutions and industry associations, including SME associations. In November, the HKMA also signed a memorandum of understanding with the Hong Kong Chinese Enterprises Association to help mainland enterprises in Hong Kong to better understand and make more use of our CTC platform.

# Promotion of asset management business

The HKMA continued to promote Hong Kong as an asset management centre. According to the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC), the number of licensed corporations engaged in asset management was 1,300 at the end of 2016, an increase of nearly 15% year-on-year. According to the Asian Venture Capital Journal, the number of private equity firms in Hong Kong (including SFC-licensed and non-SFC-licensed firms) also increased by 4.6% to 431 in 2016. To date, nearly 70 of the world’s top 100 asset management companies, and most of the top 20 mainland mutual fund companies, have established operations or affiliated companies in Hong Kong. The number of institutional investors, or asset owners, operating in Hong Kong has also been gradually increasing. In October, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, the world’s third largest sovereign wealth fund, announced the establishment of an overseas office in Hong Kong, its only office outside Abu Dhabi.

# Introduction of open-ended fund company structure

To attract funds to domicile in Hong Kong, the HKMA continued to work with the government and the industry to create a more favourable tax and regulatory environment. In June, the Securities and Futures (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 was passed, introducing an open-ended fund company structure to make Hong Kong’s fund domiciliation platform more diversified and to create a more flexible operating environment for fund managers, thereby enhancing Hong Kong’s competitiveness as an international asset management centre.

# Islamic finance

The HKMA continued to enhance market understanding and knowledge of Islamic finance, including co-organising and participating in Islamic finance conferences with industry associations, and sharing experience in sukuk issuance with market participants to encourage them to use Hong Kong’s platform. Following the successful issuance of the first two batches of sukuk, the HKMA and the government have been working closely to launch a third batch of sukuk when market conditions are appropriate.

# 儲備管理

2016年是充滿意外和黑天鵝事件的一年，環球金融市場出現大波動和震盪。2016年年初市場憂慮內地經濟硬着陸及全球增長放緩，促使環球股市大幅下挫。6月英國脫歐公投和11月美國大選結果亦出人意表。儘管投資環境困難，金管局在過去幾年已採取連串防禦措施，增強外匯基金的抗震能力，因此外匯基金在2016年仍錄得2% 的整體投資回報。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。外匯基金由財政司司長掌有控制權，並投資於其經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後認為合適的證券或其他資產。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合結構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：
(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產分布中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。這兩個組合整體債券與股票的長線目標分布比率為71比29。以目標貨幣比重計，91%的資產分配予美元及港元，其餘9%分配予其他貨幣。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權，以及海外投資物業。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一，但因應部分未來基金投放於長期資產，市值上限還有增加的空間。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎2，惟未來基金存款則除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2016年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重為80：20。預期截至2018年底，未來基金存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎的部分會逐步增加至約50%。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產分布及戰略性資產分布作基礎。策略性資產分布，即投資基準反映的分布情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可以作出的最佳長線資產分布。外匯基金以策略性分布作為指引，對資產進行戰略性分布，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際分布往往會與基準分布（亦即策略性分布）有所偏離，而實際與基準分布之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及戰略性偏離的限度，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產分布。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的限度內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局儲備管理部職員直接管理外匯基金約74%的投資，其中包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約26%的資產，其中包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的，是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化的投資方式，以及讓內部專業人員汲取市場知識與資訊。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

金管局支持證券及期貨事務監察委員會於2016年3月7日發布的《負責任的擁有權原則》（《原則》）。《原則》屬自願性質，旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司的投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局鼓勵獲委任負責管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理在管理有關投資時採納《原則》。

# 風險管理及監察

近年金融市場波動極大，凸顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況；另亦採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，務求能最有效地運用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# 外匯基金的表現

# 2016年的金融市場

2016年環球金融市場出現大波動和震盪。股票市場方面，1月市場憂慮內地經濟硬着陸及全球增長放緩，促使香港及其他主要股市大幅下挫，直至2月中旬市場才穩定下來。6月英國脫歐公投及11月美國大選結果相繼出人意表，但股市在經歷短暫下挫後迅速收復失地。全年計，環球股市普遍表現理想。

債券市場方面，第1季商品價格進一步下跌加深市場對全球增長放緩及低通脹的憂慮，加上第2季英國脫歐公投帶來的不明朗因素及市場對中央銀行維持寬鬆政策的預期，加大了市場對安全資產的需求，支持政府債市於2016年上半年有不俗表現。其中10年期美國國庫券收益率在7月跌至1.36%的歷史低位。然而，在下半年由於市場對美國加息的預期升溫，尤其在美國總統選舉後，美國國庫券收益率飆升。其他主要政府債券的收益率亦上升，但升幅較小。

貨幣市場方面，美元在2016年繼續走強，美元匯價指數升至14年來的高位。美元持續強勢，是受到美元與其他主要貨幣的利率差距擴大所支持。雖然日圓兌美元於2016年上升約3%，歐元兌美元下跌約3%。在英國脫歐公投結果帶來的不明朗因素持續困擾下，英鎊兌美元於年內亦下跌16%，是自2008年以來的最大跌幅。

# 外匯基金的表現

儘管金融市場大幅波動，外匯基金在2016年仍錄得681億港元投資收入，包括外地股票收益286億港元、香港股票收益53億港元、債券收益331億港元、外匯基金投資控股附屬公司持有的其他投資收益169億港元，以及非港元資產外匯估值下調158億港元。由於去年美元匯價急升，外匯基金非美元投資轉作港元時無可避免出現外匯估值下調。另一方面，策略性資產組合錄得7億港元估值虧損。

於2016年年底，外匯基金的資產總額達36,187億港元。長期增長組合投資的市值總計1,818億港元，當中包括私募股權1,168億港元及房地產650億港元，已承擔但尚未提取作投資的總額為1,338億港元。

儘管投資環境挑戰不絕，外匯基金在2016年仍錄得2%的投資回報率（不包括策略性資產組合）。長期增長組合自2009年開展投資以來的內部回報率年率約為12%。

由於外圍投資環境持續惡化，過去幾年金管局已作出一系列防禦部署，包括縮短債券組合年期、增持現金及大幅減持非美元及非港元資產。我們亦加快多元化投資的步伐，特別是長期增長組合的投資。這些部署大大增強外匯基金的抗震能力。

# Reserves Management

The year 2016 was marked by surprises and black swan events, with global financial markets experiencing significant volatility and upheaval. At the start of the year, concerns about a hard landing in the Chinese mainland economy and a global economic slowdown prompted a sharp decline in global stock markets. The results of the UK’s Brexit referendum in June and the US presidential election in November were also unexpected. Despite the challenging investment climate, the HKMA has implemented a series of defensive measures over the past few years to strengthen the Exchange Fund’s resilience, enabling it to achieve an overall investment return of 2% in 2016.

# Exchange Fund

Under the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary purpose of the Exchange Fund is to influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar directly or indirectly. It may also be used to maintain the stability and integrity of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems, thereby preserving Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre. The Exchange Fund is controlled by the Financial Secretary and is invested in securities or other assets deemed appropriate after consultation with the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee.

# Management of the Exchange Fund

# Investment objectives and portfolio structure

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has established the following investment objectives for the Exchange Fund:
(a) to safeguard capital;
(b) to ensure that the overall monetary base is fully backed by highly liquid US dollar assets at all times;
(c) to ensure sufficient liquidity to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(d) to achieve investment returns, within the constraints of (a) to (c) above, in order to preserve the Fund’s long-term purchasing power.

These objectives fully reflect the statutory purposes of the Exchange Fund and are embodied in its portfolio structure and target asset allocation.

The Exchange Fund is broadly divided into two main portfolios: the Backing Portfolio and the Investment Portfolio. The Backing Portfolio holds highly liquid US dollar assets to fully back the monetary base, in accordance with the requirements of the Currency Board system. The Investment Portfolio is primarily invested in the bond and equity markets of Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development member countries, with the aim of preserving asset value and long-term purchasing power. The long-term target bond-to-equity ratio for these two portfolios combined is 71:29. In terms of target currency allocation, 91% of assets are denominated in US dollars and Hong Kong dollars, with the remaining 9% in other currencies.

To better manage risk and enhance medium- to long-term returns, the HKMA has prudently and progressively diversified a portion of the Exchange Fund’s assets into more varied asset classes, including emerging market and mainland Chinese bonds and equities, private equity, and overseas investment properties. Emerging market and mainland Chinese bonds and equities are held within the Investment Portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held within the Long-Term Growth Portfolio. The market value cap of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio is one-third of the Exchange Fund’s accumulated surplus, but this cap may increase as some future funds are invested in long-term assets.

The Strategic Portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares in Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited, which were purchased by the government for strategic purposes on behalf of the Exchange Fund. Due to its unique nature, this portfolio is excluded from the assessment of the Exchange Fund’s investment performance.

# Deposits in the Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund periodically accepts deposits from fiscal reserves, government funds, and statutory bodies. The interest rate is generally linked to the performance of the investment portfolio, except for deposits from the Future Fund. The interest rate for Future Fund deposits is linked to the performance of both the investment portfolio and the Long-Term Growth Portfolio, with the actual rate depending on the portfolio mix. At the end of 2016, the Future Fund’s allocation between the investment portfolio and the Long-Term Growth Portfolio was 80:20. It is expected that by the end of 2018, the portion of Future Fund deposits linked to the Long-Term Growth Portfolio will gradually increase to around 50%.

# Investment process

The Exchange Fund’s investment process is based on both strategic and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation, as reflected in the investment benchmark, represents the optimal long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund can adopt to achieve its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses this strategic allocation as a guide and makes tactical asset allocation decisions to achieve returns above the benchmark. Consequently, actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark (i.e., the strategic allocation), and the difference between actual and benchmark allocation is referred to as a “tactical deviation”. The Financial Secretary, after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, sets the investment benchmark and limits on tactical deviations. The HKMA is authorised to determine the tactical asset allocation. Portfolio managers can select holdings within the limits of tactical deviations to capitalise on short-term market changes.

# Investment management

# Direct investment

Staff from the HKMA’s Reserves Management Department directly manage approximately 74% of the Exchange Fund’s investments, including the entire Backing Portfolio and part of the Investment Portfolio. This portion of the Investment Portfolio is invested in global fixed-income markets and uses derivative instruments to implement the Exchange Fund’s macro risk management strategies.

# External managers

In addition to managing assets through internal staff, the HKMA also employs external managers to manage around 26% of the Exchange Fund’s assets, including all listed equity portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of employing external managers is to leverage the best professional investment expertise available in the market, enable the Exchange Fund to benefit from diversified investment approaches, and allow internal professionals to gain market knowledge and insights.

The costs associated with employing external managers include fund management and custodian fees, transaction fees, withholding taxes, and other taxes. These costs vary from year to year, primarily due to market factors.

The HKMA supports the Principles of Responsible Ownership published by the Securities and Futures Commission on 7 March 2016. These Principles are voluntary and aim to help investors determine how best to fulfil their ownership responsibilities in relation to their investments in Hong Kong-listed companies. When managing the Exchange Fund, the HKMA encourages external fund managers responsible for Hong Kong equity portfolios to adopt these Principles in their investment management practices.

# Risk management and compliance

In recent years, significant volatility in financial markets has underscored the importance of risk management. The HKMA has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for portfolios managed by both internal and external managers and closely monitors compliance with these guidelines and regulations. It also employs risk-control tools to assess market risks under both normal and extremely adverse conditions. Furthermore, the HKMA conducts detailed performance attribution analyses to optimise the use of investment management expertise from both internal and external managers.

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

# Financial markets in 2016

Global financial markets experienced significant volatility and upheaval in 2016. In the equity markets, concerns about a hard landing in the Chinese mainland economy and a global economic slowdown in January led to sharp declines in Hong Kong and other major stock markets, which only stabilised by mid-February. The outcomes of the UK’s Brexit referendum in June and the US presidential election in November were both unexpected, but equity markets recovered quickly after brief downturns. Overall, global equity markets performed well throughout the year.

In the bond markets, further declines in commodity prices in the first quarter heightened concerns about a global economic slowdown and low inflation. Additionally, uncertainty stemming from the UK’s Brexit referendum in the second quarter and expectations of continued accommodative policies by central banks increased demand for safe assets, supporting strong performance in government bond markets during the first half of 2016. The yield on 10-year US Treasury notes fell to a historic low of 1.36% in July. However, yields on US Treasury notes surged in the second half of the year as expectations of a US interest rate hike intensified, particularly after the presidential election. Yields on other major government bonds also rose, albeit by a smaller margin.

In the currency markets, the US dollar continued to strengthen in 2016, with the US dollar index reaching a 14-year high. The sustained strength of the US dollar was supported by the widening interest rate differential between the US dollar and other major currencies. While the yen appreciated by around 3% against the US dollar in 2016, the euro depreciated by around 3%. Amid ongoing uncertainty following the UK’s Brexit referendum result, the pound fell by 16% against the US dollar during the year, marking its largest decline since 2008.

# Performance of the Exchange Fund

Despite significant market volatility, the Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$68.1 billion in 2016. This included overseas equity returns of HK$28.6 billion, Hong Kong equity returns of HK$5.3 billion, bond returns of HK$33.1 billion, other investment returns of HK$16.9 billion from the Exchange Fund’s investment holding subsidiaries, and a negative currency translation effect of HK$15.8 billion for non-Hong Kong dollar assets. Meanwhile, the Strategic Portfolio recorded a valuation loss of HK$7 billion.

At the end of 2016, the total assets of the Exchange Fund amounted to HK$3,618.7 billion. The total market value of investments in the Long-Term Growth Portfolio was HK$181.8 billion, comprising private equity of HK$116.8 billion and real estate of HK$65.0 billion, with outstanding investment commitments of HK$1,338 billion.

Despite a challenging investment environment, the Exchange Fund achieved an investment return of 2% in 2016 (excluding the Strategic Portfolio). The annualised internal rate of return of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio since its inception in 2009 has been approximately 12%.

財政司司長透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會提供的意見，並參考市場薪酬水平及做法，決定金管局員工的薪酬及服務條件。薪酬組合包括現金薪酬及公積金，另設一些基本福利。現金薪酬包括每月固定薪酬（即基本薪酬）及根據員工工作表現每年一次過發放的浮動薪酬。

財政司司長每年檢討金管局員工薪酬時，會透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的建議，並考慮管治委員會對金管局過去一年的表現評估、獨立人力資源顧問公司進行的金融業薪酬調查結果，以及其他相關因素。個別工作表現優秀的員工的薪酬亦可能獲得特別調整，以保持其薪酬競爭力。

# Corporate Functions

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) maintains effective communication with society and the market through the media, public education activities, and other channels to enhance public understanding of its policies and operations. During the year, the HKMA continued to strengthen its corporate governance, including promoting staff professional development, tightening financial control, and enhancing information technology security, to meet the challenges posed by the implementation of new measures and the increasing workload.

# Institutional Development to Maintain Public Engagement

# Public Communications

The HKMA maintains close contact with the media to enhance its transparency and improve public understanding of its policies and work. In 2016, the HKMA conducted 81 public media events, including 14 press conferences, 13 on-site interviews, and 54 other public events, and arranged 30 media interviews. During the year, 326 bilingual press releases were issued, and a large number of media enquiries were handled daily.

During the year, the HKMA established two important offices: the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) and the Financial Technology Facilitation Office (FFO). To explain their functions and work plans, the HKMA conducted various public communication activities. In addition, the HKMA organised media briefings and seminars to enhance public understanding of its operations and measures in areas such as financial inclusion, reserves management, the Fintech Supervisory Sandbox, cybersecurity, and small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) financing.

The Chief Executive of the HKMA, Mr Norman Chan, met with reporters during the Hong Kong Association of Banks’ annual Beijing trip in December 2016.

# Public Enquiries

The Public Enquiry Service provides an effective channel for citizens to obtain information about the HKMA’s functions and work. In 2016, this service handled 10,170 enquiries, a 12% increase compared to 2015. About half of the enquiries were related to banking policies and regulations, monetary and economic issues, and consumer banking matters, particularly banking products and services, the Coin Collection Programme, banking-related guidelines and circulars, stored value facilities (SVFs), retail payment systems, the prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing, and prudential measures for property mortgage loans.

Chart 1 shows the number of public enquiries received each year since 2013, and Chart 2 shows the proportion of different types of enquiries in 2016.

# Publications

In addition to the HKMA Annual Report, the HKMA published two issues of the Half-Yearly Monetary and Financial Stability Report and four issues of the Quarterly Bulletin during the year. It also regularly updated the Monthly Statistical Bulletin to provide the latest and topical information and analysis on Hong Kong’s currency, banking, and economic affairs. Furthermore, the HKMA published 32 inSight articles in 2016, a significant increase from 14 in 2015, analysing various topics related to its work.

The HKMA’s 2015 Annual Report won the Silver Award in the “Non-Profit and Charitable Organisations” category at the 2016 Best Annual Reports Awards organised by the Hong Kong Management Association.

# Public Education Programme

The HKMA Information Centre, located on the 55th floor of Two International Finance Centre, introduces the HKMA’s work to the public and enhances public understanding of monetary and banking matters. The Information Centre consists of an exhibition area and a library, both open to the public six days a week. The exhibition area introduces the HKMA’s work and the development of Hong Kong’s currency and banking sector, and provides reading materials and exhibits for research on Hong Kong’s currency, banking, and financial affairs.

The policy exhibition area of the Information Centre, which explains the HKMA’s work and introduces related financial knowledge, underwent renovation in the fourth quarter of 2016. The renovation enriched the exhibition content and added various interactive elements, particularly interactive games that combine learning with play to explain financial concepts in a simple and accessible manner. There are also colourful touchscreens that provide a more comprehensive and in-depth introduction to the HKMA’s work, aiming to offer visitors a brand-new experience. Additionally, the renovated Information Centre features a mosaic of Victoria Harbour made from over 130,000 Hong Kong coins. The newly designed policy exhibition area reopened to the public on 24 February 2017.

# HKMA Website

The HKMA’s corporate website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 50,000 pages of information in English and traditional and simplified Chinese, making it convenient for the public to access the latest information about the HKMA. The website also contains the Register of Securities Staff of Authorised Institutions and the Register of Authorised Institutions and Local Representative Offices maintained under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the Register of SVF Licensees maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance. The website features special topic pages and prominent quick links to remind the public of the HKMA’s new measures, such as the regulatory regime for SVFs, IFFO and FFO, and important and timely matters, such as precautions against telephone scams and the parking locations of coin collection carts.

The new design of the policy exhibition area at the Information Centre.

A mosaic of Victoria Harbour made from Hong Kong coins.

The Information Centre provides guided tours for visitors. During the year, the Information Centre received over 56,200 visitors and provided more than 580 guided tours for schools and other groups (Chart 3). Since its opening in December 2003, the Information Centre has cumulatively received over 586,600 visitors.

Adjacent to the exhibition area, the library houses over 23,000 books, journals, and other publications for in-depth research on Hong Kong’s currency, banking, finance, and central banking issues. The library also maintains the electronic registers of authorised institutions and local representative offices, as well as the register of securities staff of authorised institutions, as required under Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance.

To maintain contact with the community and enhance public understanding of the HKMA’s work, the HKMA continued to organise public education seminars. In 2016, the HKMA held three public seminars, attracting over 1,750 secondary school students and teachers. The topics included the linked exchange rate system, banking stability, banknotes in Hong Kong, smart tips for using banking products and services, and the Deposit Protection Scheme. Since its launch in 1998, the education seminar programme has been attended by over 56,400 citizens.

Students and teachers from various secondary schools attended one of the public education seminars.

Chart 3 Types of groups visiting the Information Centre in 2016

# Human Resources

The HKMA recruits, trains, and maintains a professional and excellent workforce to achieve its policy objectives and respond flexibly to changes in work priorities. The HKMA is part of the government structure but employs staff under non-civil service terms to attract talent with appropriate experience and expertise. As a public institution, the HKMA strives to maintain a streamlined and flexible organisational structure and implements new measures and copes with increasing workloads by redeploying existing staff as much as possible.

# Staffing

The HKMA’s staffing level was 875 at the beginning of 2016. In the second half of 2016, 12 positions were added to fulfil the HKMA’s regulatory functions under the new insurance regulatory regime. Therefore, the HKMA’s staffing level was 887 at the end of 2016.

To ensure sufficient resources for implementing new laws and policies, continuing pilot projects that need to be sustained, and handling increasingly heavy and complex existing work, the HKMA’s overall establishment increased by 40 to 927 in 2017 (a 4.5% increase). The new positions are responsible for the following functions:
- Promoting the stability of the banking and financial system, including:
    - Strengthening supervisory capacity to manage banks’ increasing technology risks and new fintech projects, and to cope with banks’ regional and business expansion;
    - Strengthening regulatory and enforcement efforts to combat money laundering and terrorist financing, and preparing for the 2018 mutual evaluation by the Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering;
    - Planning and preparing for the implementation of the Financial Institutions (Resolution) Ordinance to address the “too big to fail” issue in the financial sector in accordance with international standards; and
    - Strengthening supervisory capacity to comply with new international standards on capital and market risks, and allocating more resources to handle consumer protection matters and bank complaints.
- Strengthening investment, risk management, and other related support in response to the increased investment work involved in further promoting the diversification of Exchange Fund investment products, while enhancing strategic asset allocation and investment processes to cope with the increasingly challenging investment environment.
- Formulating and implementing talent development programmes and strengthening related resources to ensure that the HKMA has the human resources needed to respond to market developments and future challenges.
- Strengthening research on monetary policy and the processing of monetary statistics, and providing resources to handle enquiries and complaints related to licensing/designation and regulatory matters for SVFs and retail payment systems.

Table 1 shows the HKMA’s establishment and actual staff numbers by department.
Table 1: HKMA establishment and actual staff numbers as at 1 January 2017

The HKMA allocates temporary resources to handle other work and seconds staff to international or local institutions, such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the Financial Development Bureau, to assist with work or policies in which Hong Kong or the HKMA is involved. In addition, the HKMA assigns staff to the Hong Kong Deposit Protection Board and the Treasury Markets Association to provide full-time or assistance-based operational support.

# Remuneration Policies and Salary Review Mechanism

The Financial Secretary determines the remuneration and terms of service of HKMA employees through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee (eFAC), taking into account the views of its Governance Sub-Committee (GSC) and market remuneration levels and practices. The remuneration package includes cash remuneration and a provident fund scheme, as well as some basic benefits. Cash remuneration consists of a monthly fixed salary (i.e. basic salary) and variable pay based on annual employee performance.

When reviewing HKMA employees’ salaries annually, the Financial Secretary seeks advice from the GSC of the eFAC and considers the GSC’s assessment of the HKMA’s performance in the previous year, the results of a salary survey of the financial sector conducted by an independent human resources consultancy, and other relevant factors. The salaries of individual employees with outstanding performance may also be specially adjusted to maintain their competitiveness.

The HKMA allocates funds approved for adjusting annual fixed salaries or paying variable pay based on individual employees’ performance. The variable pay system for investment professionals is designed to strengthen the link between their investment performance and remuneration. Adjustments to the fixed salaries or payments of variable pay for Assistant Presidents or above are approved by the Financial Secretary after consulting the GSC. The employees concerned will absent themselves from meetings when their remuneration is discussed. Adjustments to the fixed salaries or payments of variable pay for Division Heads and below are determined by the Chief Executive of the HKMA under the Financial Secretary’s authorisation and in accordance with the lump sum approved for salary payments.

# 按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.5、2.6及36.1。

於2016年12月31日，集團按公平值列帳的金融資產共31,989.75億港元，金融負債共9,639.77億港元。

95%的該等金融資產及所有該等金融負債的公平值為相同資產或負債於活躍市場的報價（第1級參數），或是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第2級參數）。

其餘5%的該等金融資產的公平值，是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第3級參數）。有關金融資產共1,758.86億港元，主要包括非上市投資基金。

鑑於所涉數額龐大及涉及估計，按公平值列帳的金融資產及金 融負債的估值屬關鍵審計事項。

就按公平值列帳的金融資產及金融負債的估值，審計程序包括：
- 了解不同類別金融資產及金融負債的估值程序，包括相關監控措施；
- 評價及測試監控措施，包括電腦系統的相關應用程式監控措施；
- 就金融資產及金融負債的估值、存在、權利與責任及完整性取得函證；
- 若使用市場報價，根據獨立來源核實價格；
- 若所用估值方法的參數是以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合及有關假設是否合理，以及根據獨立來源核實參數；及
- 若所用估值方法的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎，評價估值方法是否適合，以及有關假設與參數是否合理。

# 未來基金存款

請參閱財務報表附註2.6、2.16.1、4(b)、23及28。

在以往年度，財政儲備的絕大部分存款均須於要求時償還，並按每年參考投資組合過去的投資回報釐定的固定息率計算利息。

政府於2016年1月1日在財政儲備內設立未來基金。未來基金存款包含來自土地基金結餘的首筆資金（為數2,197.30億港元），以及從政府一般收入帳目轉撥的恆常注資（金額由財政司司長指示）。未來基金存款的利息按綜合息率計算，而該綜合息率是參考上文提及與投資組合的表現掛鈎的固定息率及與長期增長組合（持有私募股權及房地產投資）的表現掛鈎的年度回報率，每年在加權平均基礎上釐定。除財政司司長另有指示外，未來基金的存款連同所賺取的利息應在2025年12月31日償還。

於2016年12月31日，未來基金的存款共2,245.30億港元。有關存款的累計利息為100.71億港元。由於涉及數額龐大及存款條件有重大改變，需要格外關注有關存款及所賺取的利息的計量、列報方式及披露資料。

就未來基金存款，審計程序包括：
- 評價計量有關存款及所賺取的利息所用的會計政策是否恰當；
- 審視與長期增長組合的表現掛鈎的年度回報率的計算方法；
- 核實參考投資組合以往的表現釐定的固定息率、與長期增長組合的表現掛鈎的年度回報率及參考該兩項息率釐定的綜合息率的計算；
- 核實以綜合息率計算的應計利息數額；及
- 審視有關存款及所賺取的利息在財務報表中的列報方式及披露資料。

# 按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值

請參閱財務報表附註2.12、17及18。

集團的投資物業按公平值列帳，於2016年12月31日共值227.23億港元。集團亦於3間聯營公司及14間合營公司擁有權益，該等公司主要業務為持有海外投資物業，有關權益共值320.83億港元。不論是由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有，該等投資物業的公平值均主要根據獨立專業估值師的估值釐定。該等估值涉及重大判斷及估計，包括所用的估值方法及假設。

就按公平值列帳的投資物業的估值，審計程序包括：
- 獲取及審視由集團直接持有或由聯營公司或合營公司持有的投資物業的估值報告，並核實公平值是根據有關估值報告所列的估值釐定；

我對財務報表的意見並不涵蓋其他資料，我亦不對其他資料發表任何形式的鑒證結論。

就財務報表審計而言，我有責任閱讀其他資料，從而考慮其他資料是否與財務報表或我在審計過程中得悉的情況有重大矛盾，或者似乎存有重大錯誤陳述。基於我已執行的工作，如果我認為其他資料存有重大錯誤陳述，我需要報告該事實。在這方面，我沒有任何報告。

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而公平的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制，使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力， 以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：
- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否公允反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

# Exchange Fund

# Report of the Director of Audit

# Audit Commission of the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

# Independent Auditor’s Report to the Financial Secretary

# Opinion

I have audited the financial statements of the Exchange Fund and its subsidiaries (the “Group”) set out on pages 149 to 237, which comprise the Group’s balance sheet as at 31 December 2016, and the income and expenditure account, statement of comprehensive income, statement of changes in equity and cash flow statement for the year then ended, together with the notes to the financial statements, including a summary of significant accounting policies.

In my opinion, the financial statements present a true and fair view of the financial position of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at 31 December 2016, and of their financial performance and cash flows for the year then ended, in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants. They have also been properly prepared in accordance with the directions given by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Cap. 66).

# Basis for opinion

I conducted my audit in accordance with the directions given by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the auditing standards of the Audit Commission. My responsibilities under those standards are further described in the “Auditor’s responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements” section of my report. I am independent of the Group in accordance with those standards, and I have fulfilled my other ethical responsibilities under those standards. I believe that the audit evidence I have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my audit opinion.

# Key audit matters

Key audit matters are those matters that, in my professional judgment, were of most significance in my audit of the financial statements for the year ended 31 December 2016. These matters were addressed in the context of my audit of the financial statements as a whole, and in forming my opinion thereon, and I do not provide a separate opinion on these matters.

# Report of the Director of Audit (continued)

# Key audit matters

How I addressed these matters in my audit

# Valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value

Refer to notes 2.5, 2.6 and 36.1 to the financial statements.

As at 31 December 2016, the Group’s financial assets measured at fair value totalled HK$31,989.75 billion, and its financial liabilities totalled HK$9,639.77 billion.

The fair values of 95% of these financial assets and all of these financial liabilities were based on quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in active markets (level 1 inputs), or were estimated using valuation techniques where the inputs were based on observable market data (level 2 inputs).

The fair values of the remaining 5% of these financial assets were estimated using valuation techniques where the inputs were not based on observable market data (level 3 inputs). These financial assets totalled HK$1,758.86 billion and mainly comprised unlisted investment funds.

The valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value was a key audit matter given the significant amounts involved and the estimation required.

My audit procedures in relation to the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value included:
- Understanding the valuation processes for different categories of financial assets and financial liabilities, including related monitoring controls;
- Evaluating and testing monitoring controls, including relevant application controls in computer systems;
- Obtaining external confirmations on the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and financial liabilities;
- Verifying prices against independent sources when market quotations were used;
- When valuation techniques used inputs based on observable market data, evaluating whether the valuation techniques were appropriate and the assumptions used were reasonable, and verifying the inputs against independent sources; and
- When valuation techniques used inputs not based on observable market data, evaluating whether the valuation techniques were appropriate and the assumptions and inputs used were reasonable.

# Future Fund deposits

Refer to notes 2.6, 2.16.1, 4(b), 23 and 28 to the financial statements.

In previous years, most deposits in the fiscal reserves were repayable on demand and bore interest at a fixed rate determined annually by reference to the past investment returns of the investment portfolio.

The Government established the Future Fund within the fiscal reserves on 1 January 2016. The Future Fund deposits comprised an initial sum from the Land Fund balance (amounting to HK$2,197.30 billion) and regular injections transferred from the Government’s General Revenue Account (the amount of which was directed by the Financial Secretary). Interest on the Future Fund deposits was calculated at a composite rate, which was determined annually on a weighted average basis by reference to the fixed rate linked to the investment portfolio’s performance mentioned above and the annual rate of return linked to the performance of the long-term Growth Portfolio (which held private equity and real estate investments). Unless otherwise directed by the Financial Secretary, the Future Fund deposits together with interest earned were to be repaid on 31 December 2025.

As at 31 December 2016, the Future Fund deposits totalled HK$2,245.30 billion. The accumulated interest on these deposits was HK$100.71 billion. Given the significant amounts involved and the major changes in the terms of the deposits, extra attention was required regarding the measurement, presentation and disclosure of information relating to these deposits and the interest earned.

My audit procedures in relation to the Future Fund deposits included:
- Evaluating whether the accounting policies used to measure the deposits and interest earned were appropriate;
- Reviewing the calculation methodology of the annual rate of return linked to the performance of the long-term Growth Portfolio;
- Verifying the calculation of the fixed rate determined by reference to the past performance of the investment portfolio, the annual rate of return linked to the performance of the long-term Growth Portfolio, and the composite rate determined by reference to these two rates;
- Verifying the amount of interest accrued calculated at the composite rate; and
- Reviewing the presentation and disclosure of information relating to these deposits and interest earned in the financial statements.

# Valuation of investment properties measured at fair value

Refer to notes 2.12, 17 and 18 to the financial statements.

The Group’s investment properties were measured at fair value and totalled HK$227.23 billion as at 31 December 2016. The Group also held interests in three associates and 14 joint ventures whose principal activities were holding overseas investment properties, with interests totalling HK$320.83 billion. Regardless of whether they were held directly by the Group or by associates or joint ventures, the fair values of these investment properties were primarily determined based on valuations by independent professional valuers. These valuations involved significant judgement and estimation, including the valuation techniques and assumptions used.

My audit procedures in relation to the valuation of investment properties measured at fair value included:
- Obtaining and reviewing valuation reports for investment properties held directly by the Group or by associates or joint ventures, and verifying that the fair values were determined based on the valuations stated in those reports;
- Assessing the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and
- Evaluating whether the valuation techniques were appropriate and the assumptions and parameters used were reasonable.

# Other information

The Monetary Authority is responsible for the other information. The other information comprises all information in the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s 2016 Annual Report, but does not include the financial statements and my auditor’s report thereon.

My opinion on the financial statements does not cover the other information, and I do not express any form of assurance conclusion thereon.

In connection with my audit of the financial statements, I am responsible for reading the other information and considering whether it is materially inconsistent with the financial statements or my knowledge obtained during the audit, or otherwise appears to be materially misstated. If, based on the work I have performed, I conclude that there is a material misstatement of this other information, I am required to report that fact. I have nothing to report in this regard.

# Responsibilities of the Monetary Authority and the Audit Sub-Committee of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee for the financial statements

The Monetary Authority is responsible for preparing financial statements that present a true and fair view in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants and the directions given by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, and for implementing such internal control as it determines is necessary to enable the preparation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.

In preparing the financial statements, the Monetary Authority is responsible for assessing the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going concern basis of accounting.

The Audit Sub-Committee of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for overseeing the Group’s financial reporting process.

# Auditor’s responsibilities for the audit of the financial statements

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditor’s report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with the Audit Commission auditing standards will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these financial statements.

As part of an audit in conformity with the Audit Commission auditing standards, I exercise professional judgment and maintain professional scepticism throughout the audit. I also:
- Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control.
- Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances. However, this is not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group’s internal control.
- Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used by the Monetary Authority and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by the Monetary Authority.
- Conclude on the appropriateness of the Monetary Authority’s use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If I conclude that a material uncertainty exists, I am required to draw attention in my auditor’s report to the related disclosures in the financial statements or, if such disclosures are inadequate, to modify my opinion. My conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of my auditor’s report. However, future events or conditions may cause the Group to cease to continue as a going concern.
- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the financial statements, including the disclosures, and whether the financial statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation.
- Obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities or business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the Group audit. I bear sole responsibility for my audit opinion.

I communicate with the Audit Sub-Committee of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control that I identify during my audit.
